items.title: DUMB - A Unified Media Solution
items.text:
DUMB is an all-in-one media management and streaming solution that integrates multiple services into a single Docker image for streamlined deployment. Automate discovery, downloads, and library organization using Debrid and Usenet services, Plex Discover Watchlists, Trakt lists, Seerr, and more.

Deployment Guide Architecture

items.title: Quick Start
items.text: Get DUMB up and running in minutes with Docker, Portainer, Unraid, or other platforms.

items.title: Unified Platform
items.text: All your favorite media services in one container. Plex, Jellyfin, Emby, Sonarr, Radarr, and more‚Äîpre-configured and ready to use.

items.title: Automated Workflows
items.text: Connect Debrid and Usenet services, Trakt lists, and Plex Discover watchlists. DUMB auto-wires the stack from onboarding to streaming.

items.title: Guided Onboarding
items.text: Step-by-step setup for core services, optional tools, credentials, and embedded UIs. Start with sane defaults, then refine later.

items.title: Embedded UIs
items.text: Use Traefik to unify service UIs under one endpoint and manage everything from the DUMB dashboard.

items.title: Live Metrics
items.text: Track CPU, memory, disk, and network usage in real time with WebSocket-powered updates.

items.title: Authentication
items.text: Optional JWT auth with user management to secure the UI and API.

items.title: Auto-Update
items.text: Keep services current with scheduled updates or pinned versions.

items.title: Auto-Restart
items.text: Health checks and backoff restarts keep services resilient.

items.title: What's Included
items.text:
DUMB integrates a comprehensive ecosystem of media management tools:

Media Servers: Plex Media Server, Jellyfin, Emby Orchestrators: Riven, CLI Debrid, Plex Debrid, Decypharr, NzbDAV Automation: Sonarr, Radarr, Lidarr, Prowlarr, Whisparr, Huntarr, Profilarr Storage & Caching: Zurg, rclone Monitoring & Tools: Tautulli, Zilean, Seerr Database: PostgreSQL, pgAdmin 4, Phalanx DB

All services work together seamlessly with Plex Discover Watchlists, Trakt lists, Seerr, and more to streamline media discovery and access.

Ready to get started? Check out the Deployment Guide or explore the Features, Services, and Reference documentation.

items.title: About DUMB (Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge)
items.text: Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge (DUMB) is an all-in-one, containerized platform for managing and automating media workflows using premium debrid services (like Real-Debrid) and Usenet. Whether you're looking to automate downloads, organize libraries, mount remote content, or just reduce manual steps, DUMB aims to unify it all into a seamless experience.

items.title: Mission
items.text:
DUMB was created with a single goal:

Bridge the gap between debrid or Usenet services and traditional media server ecosystems like Plex, Jellyfin, and Emby ‚Äî with maximum automation and minimal configuration.

By directly integrating the media server itself (e.g. Plex) within the DUMB container, the platform overcomes long-standing issues like broken bind mount propagation, sync delays, and external scan conflicts common in multi-container setups.

items.title: What Makes DUMB Unique?
items.text:
Unlike other solutions that focus on one piece of the puzzle, DUMB integrates every step of the media pipeline:

  • Embedded media servers ‚Äî Plex, Jellyfin, and Emby run inside the same container, ensuring seamless access to mounted content and full internal control
  • Service coordination ‚Äî via the internal DUMB API and real-time config management
  • Automated acquisition ‚Äî with core services for discovery and orchestrators like Riven, CLI Debrid, Decypharr, and NzbDAV
  • Cloud storage mounting ‚Äî through rclone mounts direct to debrid (e.g., Real-Debrid WebDAV) or utilizing Zurg's WebDAV
  • Arr automation ‚Äî Sonarr, Radarr, Lidarr, and Whisparr handle queues, renaming, and library organization
  • Library management ‚Äî using symlinks, metadata enrichment, and optional server updates
  • Metadata caching ‚Äî with Zilean to reduce latency and boost scraping efficiency
  • Visual control ‚Äî via the DUMB Frontend for onboarding, live logs, settings, and monitoring

All services are configured through a centralized file (dumb_config.json) and can be dynamically updated at runtime via the DUMB Frontend.

Combined workflows

You can attach a single Arr instance to multiple workflows by setting core_service to a list (for example ["decypharr", "nzbdav"]). When combined, DUMB switches Arr root folders to /mnt/debrid/combined_symlinks/<slug>.

items.title: Architecture at a Glance
items.text:
DUMB is built using a modular, microservices architecture, with the following components:

Service Description DUMB API Core controller and coordination hub DUMB Frontend Graphical interface for managing services, configs, and logs Plex Media Server First-class embedded media server for direct playback of collected content Riven Debrid content orchestration (Plex, Trakt, Seerr, lists) CLI Debrid Debrid content orchestration (lists, watchlists, upgrades) Decypharr Debrid workflow for Arr download clients and symlink libraries NzbDAV Usenet WebDAV gateway and Arr download-client integration Prowlarr Indexer management and sync to Arr services Sonarr/Radarr/Lidarr/Whisparr Arr automation for movies, TV, music, and adult content Huntarr Backlog search automation and quality upgrades Zurg Handles Real-Debrid content interaction, file repair, and directory structuring rclone Mounts cloud storage into the local container for access by your media server Zilean Caches metadata and file hash lookups for performance PostgreSQL / pgAdmin Internal databases and optional management UI

You can explore how these services connect in the Services Overview page.

items.title: Community-Driven Development
items.text:
DUMB is fully open-source and community-powered. While development is led by a single maintainer, contributions of all kinds are welcome ‚Äî not just code!

You can help by:

  • ‚≠ê Starring the GitHub repo
  • Boosting or participating in the Discord community
  • Submitting feedback, bug reports, or pull requests
  • Helping others with questions or documentation improvements
  • Sponsoring the Dev through GitHub Sponsors

See the Contributing Guide for more details.

items.title: Contributing to DUMB
items.text:
Thank you for your interest in contributing to Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge (DUMB)!

We welcome all forms of contributions ‚Äî not just code.

DUMB is an open-source, community-driven project.

Whether you're a developer, power user, or just someone passionate about improving media automation, your help is always appreciated!

Thank you for helping make DUMB better for everyone!

items.title: ‚Äç Development Contributions
items.text: Want to help develop new features, fix bugs, or improve performance?

items.title: Recommended Setup
items.text:
The easiest way to contribute code is through the DUMB Dev Container, which includes all the required tools:

  • Based on: iampuid0/dumb:latest
  • Python with Black autoformatter
  • Port forwarding for common services
  • Preconfigured workspace mounts

You can find the devcontainer setup file in the repo.

items.title: How to Get Started
items.text:
1. Fork the DUMB repository
  2. Clone your fork locally
  3. Open in VS Code using Dev Containers
  4. Make your changes, format with black, and submit a pull request

If you‚Äôre not using VS Code or Dev Containers, you can also run the project via Docker with the same mounts shown in the devcontainer.json.

items.title: Non-Code Contributions
items.text: Even if you don't write code, there are plenty of ways to help!

items.title: Star the Repo
items.text: A quick way to show support is by starring the project on GitHub: github.com/I-am-PUID-0/DUMB

items.title: Join the Community
items.text:
• Ask questions or help others in the DUMB Discord server
  • Boost the server if you find it helpful
  • Share your setups and improvements

items.title: Help with Documentation
items.text:
• Found a typo or confusing section in the docs? Open an issue or pull request.
  • Suggestions and feedback on existing documentation are always welcome.

items.title: Monetary Contributions?
items.text: • Sponsor the Dev through GitHub Sponsors

items.title: Roadmap & Feedback
items.text:
If you have ideas, feature requests, or feedback:

  • Create a GitHub Issue

  • Discuss in the community before starting larger PRs

items.title: DUMB API
items.text:
DUMB includes a built-in REST API and WebSocket server to allow programmatic control of services, logging, and system state.

The API is enabled and configured using the dumb_config.json under the dumb.api_service section. For example:

"api_service": {
  "enabled": true,
  "process_name": "DUMB API",
  "log_level": "INFO",
  "host": "127.0.0.1",
  "port": 8000
}

items.title: Features
items.text:
• Authentication - JWT-based user authentication and management
  • Health checks - Container and service health monitoring
  • Process management - Start, stop, restart services
  • Real-time streaming - WebSocket endpoints for logs, status, and metrics
  • Configuration - View and update settings (in-memory and persistent)
  • Environment state inspection - Service and system information

items.title: Common Endpoints
items.text: Method Path Description GET /api/auth/status Get authentication status POST /api/auth/login Authenticate and get JWT tokens POST /api/auth/refresh Refresh access token GET /health Container health check GET /process/processes List all services in dumb_config.json GET /process Get a specific service by process_name POST /process/start-service Start a specific service POST /process/stop-service Stop a specific service POST /process/restart-service Restart a specific service GET /process/service-status Get the current status of a service POST /process/start-core-service Start core services + dependencies GET /process/capabilities Get backend feature flags GET /seerr-sync/status Seerr Sync summary status GET /seerr-sync/failed Seerr Sync failed request list GET /seerr-sync/state Seerr Sync raw state (debug) POST /seerr-sync/test Test Seerr URL + API key DELETE /seerr-sync/failed Clear failed Seerr Sync requests GET /logs Read service log chunks WS /ws/logs Real-time log streaming WS /ws/status Real-time service status updates WS /ws/metrics Real-time system metrics

items.title: Directory Structure
items.text:
The DUMB API is split into the following modules:

File Purpose api_service.py Initializes and launches the FastAPI app api_state.py Tracks and updates service runtime state connection_manager.py Manages WebSocket client connections config.py Endpoints for working with dumb_config.json and service configs health.py Health check endpoint for validating API status logs.py REST endpoint for reading historical logs websocket_logs.py WebSocket server for streaming real-time logs to frontend process.py Service control for backend processes (start, stop, restart) seerr_sync.py Seerr Sync status and failure endpoints

items.title: API Documentation
items.text:
DUMB provides built-in API documentation through two convenient endpoints:

  • FastAPI Swagger UI Accessible at: http://<host>:<port>/docs This interface allows for interactive testing and exploring of all available REST endpoints.

  • Scalar (ReDoc-style) Docs Accessible at: http://<host>:<port>/scalar A clean, read-only view of the full OpenAPI schema for the DUMB API.

These are helpful for development, debugging, and integrating external systems with DUMB.

items.title: Next Steps
items.text:
Click on any of the modules in the sidebar to explore endpoint structure, usage examples, and development guidelines for extending the DUMB API:

  • Authentication
  • Health Check
  • Process Management
  • Configuration
  • Logs
  • WebSocket
  • WebSocket Logs
  • Seerr Sync

items.title: Authentication API
items.text: The Authentication API provides endpoints for user management, login, token handling, and authentication configuration.

items.title: Overview
items.text: All authentication endpoints are prefixed with /api/auth. When authentication is enabled, most other API endpoints require a valid JWT token in the Authorization: Bearer <token> header.

items.title: GET /api/auth/status
items.text: Returns the current authentication status.

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "enabled": true,
  "has_users": true,
  "setup_skipped": false
}
Field Type Description enabled boolean Whether authentication is currently required has_users boolean Whether any user accounts exist setup_skipped boolean Whether initial setup was skipped

items.title: POST /api/auth/login
items.text: Authenticates a user and returns JWT tokens.

items.title: Request body
items.text:
{
  "username": "admin",
  "password": "yourpassword"
}

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "access_token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIs...",
  "refresh_token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIs...",
  "token_type": "bearer"
}

items.title: Error responses
items.text: Status Description 401 Invalid credentials 403 User account is disabled

items.title: Example
items.text:
curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/api/auth/login \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"username": "admin", "password": "yourpassword"}'

items.title: POST /api/auth/refresh
items.text: Exchanges a refresh token for new access and refresh tokens.

items.title: Request body
items.text:
{
  "refresh_token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIs..."
}

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "access_token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIs...",
  "refresh_token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIs...",
  "token_type": "bearer"
}

items.title: Error responses
items.text: Status Description 401 Invalid or expired refresh token

items.title: POST /api/auth/verify
items.text: Verifies that an access token is valid.

items.title: Request body
items.text:
{
  "token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIs..."
}

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "valid": true,
  "username": "admin"
}

items.title: POST /api/auth/setup
items.text: Creates the first user account and enables authentication. Only works when no users exist.

items.title: Request body
items.text:
{
  "username": "admin",
  "password": "yourpassword"
}

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "message": "User created successfully",
  "access_token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIs...",
  "refresh_token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIs..."
}

items.title: Error responses
items.text: Status Description 400 Users already exist 422 Invalid username or password format

items.title: POST /api/auth/skip-setup
items.text: Skips the initial setup wizard, leaving authentication disabled.

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "message": "Setup skipped, authentication disabled"
}

items.title: POST /api/auth/enable
items.text: Enables authentication. Requires at least one user to exist.

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "message": "Authentication enabled"
}

items.title: Error responses
items.text: Status Description 400 No users exist - create a user first

items.title: POST /api/auth/disable
items.text:
Disables authentication, allowing unauthenticated access to all endpoints.

Security warning

Disabling authentication exposes all DUMB functionality without any access control.

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "message": "Authentication disabled"
}

items.title: User management endpoints
items.text: These endpoints require authentication when auth is enabled.

items.title: GET /api/auth/users
items.text: Lists all user accounts.

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "users": [
    {
      "username": "admin",
      "disabled": false
    },
    {
      "username": "readonly",
      "disabled": true
    }
  ]
}

items.title: POST /api/auth/users
items.text: Creates a new user account.

items.title: Request body
items.text:
{
  "username": "newuser",
  "password": "userpassword"
}

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "message": "User created successfully",
  "username": "newuser"
}

items.title: Error responses
items.text: Status Description 400 Username already exists 422 Invalid username or password format

items.title: PUT /api/auth/users/{username}
items.text: Updates a user account (enable/disable).

items.title: Path parameters
items.text: Parameter Type Description username string The username to update

items.title: Request body
items.text:
{
  "disabled": true
}

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "message": "User updated successfully",
  "username": "readonly",
  "disabled": true
}

items.title: Error responses
items.text: Status Description 400 Cannot disable the last active user 404 User not found

items.title: DELETE /api/auth/users/{username}
items.text: Deletes a user account.

items.title: Path parameters
items.text: Parameter Type Description username string The username to delete

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "message": "User deleted successfully"
}

items.title: Error responses
items.text: Status Description 400 Cannot delete the last active user 404 User not found

items.title: Token structure
items.text:
JWT tokens contain the following claims:

{
  "sub": "admin",
  "exp": 1704067200,
  "type": "access"
}
Claim Description sub Username (subject) exp Expiration timestamp (Unix epoch) type Token type: access or refresh

items.title: Token lifetimes
items.text: Token Type Default Lifetime Access Token 60 minutes Refresh Token 30 days

items.title: Using authentication with other endpoints
items.text:
When authentication is enabled, include the access token in the Authorization header:

curl -X GET http://localhost:8000/api/process/processes \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIs..."

items.title: WebSocket authentication
items.text:
For WebSocket connections, pass the token as a query parameter:

ws://localhost:8000/ws/status?token=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIs...

items.title: Common error responses
items.text: Status Error Description 401 Unauthorized Missing or invalid token 401 Token expired Access token has expired 403 Forbidden User account is disabled 422 Validation Error Invalid request body

items.title: Token refresh flow
items.text:
When receiving a 401 response:

  1. Send the refresh token to POST /api/auth/refresh
  2. If successful, retry the original request with the new access token
  3. If refresh fails, redirect the user to login

items.title: Related pages
items.text:
• Authentication Feature Guide
  • WebSocket API
  • Process Management API

items.title: Configuration API
items.text: The Configuration API is responsible for exposing endpoints that manage and manipulate DUMB's configuration settings (dumb_config.json). These endpoints provide tools for loading, updating, saving, and validating configuration data for all DUMB services.

items.title: Module: config.py
items.text: Located in: api/routers/config.py

items.title: GET /config
items.text:
Description: Returns the currently loaded in-memory configuration. You can optionally pass process_name to fetch a single service block.

Usage Example: 

curl http://localhost:8000/config

items.title: POST /config
items.text:
Description: Updates config in memory. When process_name is provided, it updates only that service block and can optionally persist to disk. Without process_name, it performs a global update.

Request Body: 

{
  "process_name": "Riven Backend",
  "updates": {
    "log_level": "DEBUG"
  },
  "persist": true
}

Usage Example: 

curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/config \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"process_name":"Riven Backend","updates":{"log_level":"DEBUG"},"persist":true}'

items.title: GET /config/schema
items.text:
Description: Returns the JSON schema used for config validation.

Usage Example: 

curl http://localhost:8000/config/schema

items.title: POST /config/process-config/schema
items.text:
Description: Returns the config schema subtree for a specific process_name.

Request Body: 

{
  "process_name": "Riven Backend"
}

Usage Example: 

curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/config/process-config/schema \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"process_name":"Riven Backend"}'

items.title: POST /config/service-config
items.text:
Description: Reads or updates a service-specific config file (JSON/YAML/CONF/Python/XML). If updates is omitted, the raw config is returned.

Request Body: 

{
  "service_name": "Zurg w/ RealDebrid",
  "updates": ""
}

Usage Example: 

curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/config/service-config \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"service_name":"Zurg w/ RealDebrid"}'

items.title: GET /config/service-ui
items.text:
Description: Returns a list of enabled services with UI ports and the current service UI toggle state.

Response: 

{
  "enabled": true,
  "services": [
    {
      "name": "Riven Frontend",
      "port": 3000,
      "path": "/service/ui/riven_frontend"
    },
    {
      "name": "pgAdmin 4",
      "port": 5050,
      "path": "/service/ui/pgadmin"
    }
  ]
}

items.title: POST /config/service-ui
items.text:
Description: Enables or disables the embedded service UI feature. When enabled, Traefik routes are configured to proxy service UIs through the DUMB frontend.

Request Body: 

{
  "enabled": true
}

Response: 

{
  "message": "Service UI enabled",
  "enabled": true
}

items.title: GET /config/onboarding-status
items.text: Description: Returns whether onboarding is required.

items.title: POST /config/onboarding-completed
items.text: Description: Marks onboarding as complete.

items.title: POST /config/reset-onboarding
items.text:
Description: Resets onboarding to incomplete.

Developer Notes

  • The config is held in memory for fast access and allows the user to experiment or preview changes before committing them to file.
  • Validation uses internal DUMB schema checks to ensure required keys and structure.
  • Routes include error handling for malformed config data.

items.title: Related Pages
items.text:
• Services Overview
  • Logs

items.title: Health Check API
items.text: The Health Check API provides a simple mechanism to verify that the DUMB container and core services are operational.

items.title: GET /health
items.text: Returns a JSON response indicating whether the container is healthy.

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "status": "healthy"
}

If the check fails, the status will be "unhealthy" and include diagnostic output.

Use Cases

  • Used by orchestrators or monitoring tools to confirm container availability.
  • Use in load balancers or uptime monitoring dashboards.

items.title: Implementation
items.text:
This route executes a background health check script in the container: 

/healthcheck.py
It runs within the same virtual environment as DUMB and ensures all critical files, paths, and subprocesses are functional.

items.title: Related
items.text:
• API Overview
  • Process Management

items.title: Logs API
items.text: The Logs API allows clients to retrieve recent logs captured by DUMB and served through the API.

items.title: Endpoint
items.text: GET /logs

items.title: Query Parameters
items.text: Parameter Type Description process_name string Required process name (e.g., Riven Backend, Zurg w/ RealDebrid). cursor int Last byte offset returned by the API (omit for first request). tail_bytes int Initial bytes to read from the end when no cursor (default: 131072).

items.title: Example Request
items.text:
GET /logs?process_name=Riven%20Backend

This request fetches the latest log chunk for the specified service.

items.title: Response Format
items.text:
Returns a JSON object containing the log chunk and cursor:

{
  "process_name": "Riven Backend",
  "cursor": 123456,
  "chunk": "Apr 12, 2025 10:04:01 - INFO - Riven Backend started\n",
  "reset": true,
  "log": "Apr 12, 2025 10:04:01 - INFO - Riven Backend started\n"
}

Important Notes

  • When reset is true, clients should replace their log buffer with chunk.
  • On incremental requests, pass the returned cursor to get only new bytes.

items.title: Related
items.text:
• Real-Time WebSocket Logs for live streaming logs.
  • Process Management for interacting with services whose logs may be captured here.

items.title: Process Management API
items.text: The Process Management endpoints handle launching, stopping, restarting, and tracking subprocesses managed by DUMB.

items.title: Lifecycle flow
items.text:
%%{ init: { "flowchart": { "curve": "basis" } } }%%
flowchart TD
    A([Start or restart request])
    B{Endpoint}
    C[Start core service<br/>/process/start-core-service]
    D[Start or restart service<br/>/process/start-service or /process/restart-service]
    E[Validate + persist config]
    F[Run setup hooks]
    G{Port conflict?}
    H[Adjust ports + save]
    I[Launch process]
    J([Status + logs])

    A ==> B
    B -- Core service --> C
    B -- Single service --> D
    C ==> E
    E ==> F
    F ==> G
    G -- Yes --> H
    G -- No --> I
    H ==> I
    D ==> F
    I ==> J

items.title: GET /process/processes
items.text: Returns all configured processes, including enabled status, version, repo URL, and sponsorship URL.

items.title: Example Response:
items.text:
{
  "processes": [
    {
      "name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid",
      "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid",
      "enabled": true,
      "config": { "enabled": true, "...": "..." },
      "version": "1.65.1",
      "key": "rclone",
      "config_key": "rclone",
      "repo_url": "https://rclone.org",
      "sponsorship_url": "https://rclone.org/sponsor/"
    }
  ]
}

items.title: GET /process
items.text: Fetch details about a specific process.

items.title: Required Query Parameter:
items.text: • process_name (string)

items.title: Optional Query Parameter:
items.text:
• scope (string): runtime (default) or all
    • runtime returns runtime/configured hard dependencies
    • all additionally includes soft linkage edges (for example optional Zilean integrations)
  • response includes parallel_groups metadata to describe concurrent prerequisite/dependent stages around the selected service

items.title: Example Response:
items.text:
{
  "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid",
  "config": { "enabled": true, "...": "..." },
  "version": "1.65.1",
  "config_key": "rclone"
}

items.title: POST /process/start-service
items.text: Starts a specific process.

items.title: Request Body:
items.text:
{
  "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid"
}

items.title: Example Response:
items.text:
{
  "status": "Service started successfully",
  "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid"
}

items.title: POST /process/stop-service
items.text: Stops a running process.

items.title: Request Body:
items.text:
{
  "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid"
}

items.title: POST /process/restart-service
items.text: Restarts a running process.

items.title: Request Body:
items.text:
{
  "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid"
}

items.title: GET /process/service-status
items.text: Gets the current status of a process.

items.title: Example Response:
items.text:
{
  "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid",
  "status": "running"
}

items.title: POST /process/start-core-service
items.text:
Starts one or more core services and all required dependencies. This is used during onboarding.

The core_services field can be a single object or an array. The name can be the config key (e.g., riven_backend) or a display name (e.g., Riven).

items.title: Request Body Examples:
Example Response:
items.text:
{
  "results": [
    {"service": "riven_backend", "status": "started"},
    {"service": "decypharr", "status": "started"}
  ],
  "errors": []
}

Notes

  • Dependencies like Zurg or rclone are created using templates and attached to the calling core service.
  • Optional services such as pgadmin or zilean are started only if included.
  • debrid_key is injected into Zurg or Decypharr as needed.
  • service_options can override config values such as log_level, port, or enabled.
  • Any startup errors appear in the errors list.

items.title: GET /process/core-services
items.text: Returns the available core services, their dependencies, and default service options (used by onboarding).

items.title: GET /process/dependency-graph
items.text:
Returns backend-resolved dependency relationships for a specific process, including:

  • static core dependencies (with instance-scoped matching for rclone/zurg)
  • inferred links from core_service/core_services
  • inferred links from wait_for_url/wait_for_dir entries (including localhost port matching)
  • inferred links from wait_for_mounts by matching required mount paths to provider service mount points
  • rclone provider links (zurg_enabled, decypharr_enabled, key_type=nzbdav) to reflect WebDAV provider dependencies directly
  • non-core hard dependency map for service-specific startup requirements (for example riven_frontend -> riven_backend, zilean -> postgres, pgadmin -> postgres)
  • conditional startup dependencies from the backend startup ordering logic -- config-aware dependencies like tautulli -> plex (when plex is enabled), prowlarr -> sonarr/radarr (when those arrs are enabled), huntarr -> sonarr (when sonarr has use_huntarr enabled), etc. For instance-scoped services (rclone, zurg), conditional deps are filtered per-instance so that only the specific associated instances are shown (for example, a rclone instance with zurg_enabled only shows its own zurg instance, not zurg instances belonging to other rclone configurations)
  • documented integration links (soft linkage, scope=all only) -- for example seerr -> sonarr/radarr request routing
  • per-process status state used by the frontend dependency graph panel
  • dependency_truth_table describing the 12 dependency signal types and whether each is treated as hard dependency vs linkage
  • signals array on each row/edge identifying which detection signals established the relationship (for example ["core_service_map"], ["rclone_provider_zurg", "conditional_startup_map"])

items.title: Required Query Parameter:
items.text: • process_name (string)

items.title: Example Response (shape):
items.text:
{
  "process_name": "Seerr Main",
  "config_key": "seerr",
  "context": { "mode": "core", "key": "seerr", "core": { "key": "seerr", "name": "Seerr", "dependencies": [] } },
  "scope": "runtime",
  "startup_order": [{ "key": "seerr", "label": "Seerr", "state": "running" }],
  "dependency_rows": [],
  "dependent_rows": [],
  "linked_outgoing_rows": [{ "process_name": "Plex Media Server", "key": "plex", "label": "Plex Media Server", "state": "running" }],
  "linked_incoming_rows": [],
  "nodes": [{ "id": "Seerr Main", "process_name": "Seerr Main", "key": "seerr", "label": "Seerr Main", "state": "running" }],
  "edges": [{ "source": "Seerr Main", "target": "Plex Media Server", "signals": ["wait_for_url"], "strength": "hard_runtime" }],
  "parallel_groups": [{ "id": "pre_core", "label": "Parallel prerequisites", "type": "parallel", "members": ["PostgreSQL", "Rclone w/ Riven"] }],
  "updated_at": "2026-02-11T18:45:00Z"
}

items.title: GET /process/optional-services
items.text: Returns optional services. You can pass core_service and optional_services query params to tailor the list.

items.title: POST /process/symlink-repair
items.text:
Runs symlink target rewrites for service symlink trees (Decypharr, NzbDAV, CLI Debrid, Riven).

Use this endpoint when mount paths change and existing symlink targets need to be rewritten.

items.title: Request Body:
items.text:
{
  "dry_run": true,
  "include_broken": true,
  "presets": ["decypharr_beta_consolidated"],
  "roots": ["/mnt/debrid/decypharr_symlinks", "/mnt/debrid/clid_symlinks"],
  "root_migrations": [
    {
      "from_root": "/mnt/debrid/decypharr_symlinks",
      "to_root": "/mnt/debrid/combined_symlinks"
    }
  ],
  "overwrite_existing": false,
  "copy_instead_of_move": false,
  "rewrite_rules": [
    {
      "from_prefix": "/mnt/debrid/old",
      "to_prefix": "/mnt/debrid/new"
    }
  ],
  "backup_path": "/config/symlink-repair/manifest.json"
}

items.title: Behavior
items.text:
• dry_run: true scans and reports without changing symlinks.
  • dry_run: false rewrites matching symlinks in place.
  • process_name is optional but recommended for async runs/job lookup.
  • Provide at least one of: presets, rewrite_rules, root_migrations.
  • root_migrations moves symlink entries from one symlink tree to another while preserving relative paths. This is intended for individual-root to combined-root migrations.
  • overwrite_existing controls behavior when a destination symlink already exists during root migration.
  • copy_instead_of_move (root migration mode) creates destination symlinks and keeps source symlinks in place.
  • If roots is omitted, backend defaults are used: /mnt/debrid/decypharr_symlinks, /mnt/debrid/nzbdav-symlinks, /mnt/debrid/combined_symlinks, /mnt/debrid/clid_symlinks, and riven_backend.symlink_library_path when configured.
  • backup_path is written only for non-dry-run operations with changes.

items.title: Example Response:
items.text:
{
  "dry_run": true,
  "scanned_symlinks": 2451,
  "changed": 312,
  "moved": 120,
  "copied": 0,
  "skipped_unchanged": 2139,
  "errors": [],
  "changes": []
}

items.title: POST /process/symlink-repair-async
items.text:
Queues symlink repair as a background job and returns immediately.

Use GET /process/symlink-job-status (or /process/symlink-job-latest) to track completion.

items.title: Response (example)
items.text:
{
  "status": "queued",
  "job_id": "76d1a3bd35f84e3fab0cc39f81246849",
  "operation": "symlink_repair"
}

items.title: POST /process/symlink-manifest/backup
items.text: Creates a standalone snapshot manifest of symlink entries for later restore.

items.title: Request Body:
items.text:
{
  "backup_path": "/config/symlink-repair/snapshots/latest.json",
  "roots": ["/mnt/debrid/decypharr_symlinks", "/mnt/debrid/clid_symlinks"],
  "include_broken": true
}

items.title: Behavior
items.text:
• Writes a manifest containing link_path + target entries.
  • If roots is omitted, backend default symlink roots are used.
  • Used by the internal DUMB scheduler when symlink_backup_enabled is set on supported services.
  • Scheduled runs can prune older manifests when symlink_backup_retention_count is greater than 0.

items.title: POST /process/symlink-manifest/backup-async
items.text: Queues a standalone snapshot backup as a background job and returns immediately.

items.title: Response (example)
items.text:
{
  "status": "queued",
  "job_id": "8e9fd0fbe88d4a6fbb2f3f77b2a3f8c1",
  "operation": "symlink_manifest_backup"
}

items.title: GET /process/symlink-job-status
items.text: Returns status/result for background symlink jobs.

items.title: Query Params
items.text: • job_id (required)

items.title: Response fields
items.text:
• status: queued, running, completed, or error
  • result: operation payload when completed
  • error: error payload when failed
  • created_at, updated_at, started_at, finished_at timestamps (when available)

items.title: GET /process/symlink-job-latest
items.text: Returns the latest symlink job for a process/operation (optionally only active jobs).

items.title: Query Params
items.text:
• process_name (required)
  • operation (optional, default symlink_manifest_backup)
  • active_only (optional, default true)

items.title: POST /process/symlink-manifest/restore
items.text: Restores symlinks from a previously generated snapshot manifest.

items.title: Request Body:
items.text:
{
  "manifest_path": "/config/symlink-repair/snapshots/latest.json",
  "dry_run": true,
  "overwrite_existing": false,
  "restore_broken": true
}

items.title: Behavior
items.text:
• dry_run: true previews restore actions without writing.
  • overwrite_existing controls whether existing paths are replaced.
  • restore_broken controls whether entries with currently missing targets are restored.

items.title: GET /process/symlink-manifest/compare
items.text: Compares a snapshot manifest against current filesystem state and returns projected restore outcomes.

items.title: Query Params
items.text:
• manifest_path (required)
  • overwrite_existing (optional, default false)
  • restore_broken (optional, default true)
  • sample_limit (optional, default 50, max 200)

items.title: Behavior
items.text:
• Uses the same overwrite/missing-target rules as restore.
  • Returns projected counts (projected_restored, skipped categories, errors).
  • Returns sample_changes with representative actions (create, overwrite, skip_*) for quick review before apply.

items.title: POST /process/symlink-manifest/restore-async
items.text:
Queues restore as a background job and returns immediately.

Use GET /process/symlink-job-status (or /process/symlink-job-latest) to track completion.

items.title: GET /process/symlink-backup-status
items.text: Returns current symlink-backup scheduler state for a service.

items.title: GET /process/symlink-backup-manifests
items.text: Lists backup manifests that match the current service symlink_backup_path template.

items.title: GET /process/symlink-manifest-files
items.text:
Lists files from the directory of a provided manifest_path (defaults to /config/symlink-repair/snapshots/latest.json directory).

Use this to populate manifest pickers in the Snapshot tab for quick restore/overwrite selection.

items.title: POST /process/symlink-backup/reschedule
items.text: Rebuilds symlink-backup schedule state from current service config.

items.title: Request Body:
items.text:
{
  "process_name": "Decypharr"
}

items.title: GET /process/capabilities
items.text: Returns backend capabilities and feature flags. Used by the frontend to determine available features.

items.title: Example Response:
items.text:
{
  "optional_only_onboarding": true,
  "optional_service_options": true,
  "manual_update_check": true,
  "seerr_sync": true,
  "auto_update_start_time": true,
  "symlink_repair": true,
  "symlink_repair_async": true,
  "symlink_manifest_backup": true,
  "symlink_manifest_backup_async": true,
  "symlink_job_status": true,
  "symlink_job_latest": true,
  "symlink_manifest_restore": true,
  "symlink_manifest_restore_async": true,
  "symlink_manifest_compare": true,
  "symlink_backup_schedule": true,
  "symlink_backup_manifest_list": true,
  "symlink_manifest_file_list": true
}
Field Description optional_only_onboarding Whether onboarding can skip core service selection optional_service_options Whether optional service options are exposed for onboarding manual_update_check Whether manual update check/install routes are available seerr_sync Whether Seerr sync feature routes are available auto_update_start_time Whether anchored auto-update start time is supported symlink_repair Whether /process/symlink-repair is available symlink_repair_async Whether /process/symlink-repair-async is available symlink_manifest_backup Whether /process/symlink-manifest/backup is available symlink_manifest_backup_async Whether /process/symlink-manifest/backup-async is available symlink_job_status Whether /process/symlink-job-status is available symlink_job_latest Whether /process/symlink-job-latest is available symlink_manifest_restore Whether /process/symlink-manifest/restore is available symlink_manifest_restore_async Whether /process/symlink-manifest/restore-async is available symlink_manifest_compare Whether /process/symlink-manifest/compare is available symlink_backup_schedule Whether scheduled symlink backup status/reschedule routes are available symlink_backup_manifest_list Whether /process/symlink-backup-manifests is available symlink_manifest_file_list Whether /process/symlink-manifest-files is available

Important Notes

  • All process names are matched against the entries defined in dumb_config.json.
  • Most process commands are defined as arrays and are managed with subprocess handling inside Python.

items.title: Related Files
items.text:
• process.py
  • Configuration

items.title: Seerr Sync API
items.text:
Seerr Sync provides one-way request replication from a primary Seerr instance to one or more subordinates.

It polls the primary at a configurable interval, fingerprints requests using {mediaType}:{tmdbId}:{is4k}, and persists sync state in /config/seerr_sync_state.json to survive restarts.

items.title: GET /api/seerr-sync/status
items.text:
Summary status of the sync service.

Response (disabled):

{
  "enabled": false,
  "status": "disabled"
}

Response (active):

{
  "enabled": true,
  "status": "active",
  "last_poll": "2026-01-29T21:32:46Z",
  "next_poll": "2026-01-29T21:33:46Z",
  "poll_interval_seconds": 60,
  "total_requests_tracked": 1284,
  "total_failed": 9,
  "subordinates": {
    "internal:Sync1": { "synced": 1280, "failed": 5 },
    "internal:Sync2": { "synced": 1281, "failed": 4 }
  }
}

Response (initializing):

{
  "enabled": true,
  "status": "initializing",
  "message": "Sync state not yet created"
}

items.title: GET /api/seerr-sync/failed
items.text:
List failed sync attempts with details.

{
  "count": 9,
  "failed_requests": [
    {
      "fingerprint": "movie:1403290:False",
      "subordinate": "internal:Sync1",
      "media_type": "movie",
      "tmdb_id": 1403290,
      "error": "[TMDB] Failed to fetch movie details: Request failed with status code 404",
      "failed_at": "2026-01-29T21:29:37Z"
    }
  ]
}

items.title: GET /api/seerr-sync/state
items.text:
Raw sync state (debugging).

{
  "last_poll_ts": "2026-01-29T21:32:46Z",
  "requests": {
    "movie:12345:False": {
      "primary_id": 42,
      "subordinates": {
        "internal:Sync1": { "id": 15, "status": 2, "synced_at": "2026-01-29T21:10:00Z" }
      }
    }
  },
  "failed": {
    "movie:1403290:False||internal:Sync1": {
      "failed_at": "2026-01-29T21:29:37Z",
      "error": "[TMDB] Failed to fetch movie details...",
      "media_type": "movie",
      "tmdb_id": 1403290
    }
  }
}

items.title: POST /api/seerr-sync/test
items.text:
Test connectivity to a Seerr instance using a URL and API key.

Request body:

{
  "url": "https://seerr.example.com",
  "api_key": "your_api_key"
}

Response (success):

{
  "ok": true,
  "status": {
    "version": "1.0.0"
  }
}

Response (failure):

{
  "detail": "Seerr responded with HTTP 401"
}

items.title: DELETE /api/seerr-sync/failed
items.text:
Clear failed requests so they are retried on the next poll.

Query parameters:

  • fingerprint (optional) ‚Äì Clear only a specific request.

Response:

{
  "message": "Cleared 9 failed request(s)",
  "cleared": 9
}

items.title: Notes
items.text:
• Timestamps are ISO 8601 UTC (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ).
  • Failed requests are retried after the configured delay.
  • Subordinate identifiers use internal:<InstanceName> or external labels when configured.

items.title: WebSocket API
items.text: DUMB provides three WebSocket endpoints for real-time streaming of logs, service status, and system metrics.

items.title: Overview
items.text:
Endpoint Purpose Data Type /ws/logs Real-time log streaming Text lines /ws/status Service status updates JSON /ws/metrics System metrics updates JSON

All WebSocket endpoints support authentication via query parameter when auth is enabled.

items.title: Authentication
items.text:
When authentication is enabled, include the access token as a query parameter:

ws://localhost:8000/ws/status?token=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIs...

If the token is missing or invalid, the connection will be rejected with a close code.

items.title: Endpoint
items.text:
/ws/status

Streams real-time service status updates including running state, health status, and restart counts.

items.title: Query parameters
items.text: Parameter Type Default Description interval float 2 Update interval in seconds (0.5-10) health boolean true Include health check results token string - JWT access token (required if auth enabled)

items.title: Connection example
items.text:
const ws = new WebSocket('ws://localhost:8000/ws/status?interval=2&health=true&token=...');

ws.onmessage = (event) => {
  const data = JSON.parse(event.data);
  console.log(data);
};

items.title: Message format
items.text:
{
  "type": "status",
  "processes": [
    {
      "process_name": "Riven Backend",
      "status": "running",
      "healthy": true,
      "health_reason": null,
      "restart": {
        "count": 0,
        "last_restart": null,
        "enabled": true
      }
    },
    {
      "process_name": "Zurg w/ RealDebrid",
      "status": "running",
      "healthy": true,
      "health_reason": null,
      "restart": {
        "count": 2,
        "last_restart": "2025-01-15T10:30:00Z",
        "enabled": true
      }
    }
  ]
}

items.title: Field descriptions
items.text: Field Type Description process_name string Service display name status string running, stopped, or unknown healthy boolean Health check result health_reason string Reason if unhealthy restart.count integer Number of auto-restarts restart.last_restart string ISO timestamp of last restart restart.enabled boolean Whether auto-restart is enabled

items.title: Endpoint
items.text:
/ws/metrics

Streams real-time system metrics including CPU, memory, disk, and network usage.

items.title: Query parameters
items.text: Parameter Type Default Description interval float 2 Update interval in seconds (0.5-10) history boolean false Include historical metrics on connect bootstrap boolean true Send initial snapshot immediately token string - JWT access token (required if auth enabled)

items.title: Connection example
items.text:
const ws = new WebSocket('ws://localhost:8000/ws/metrics?interval=2&history=true&token=...');

ws.onmessage = (event) => {
  const data = JSON.parse(event.data);

  if (data.type === 'snapshot') {
    // Current metrics
    updateDashboard(data.data);
  } else if (data.type === 'history') {
    // Historical data for charts
    initializeCharts(data.items);
  }
};

items.title: Snapshot message format
items.text:
{
  "type": "snapshot",
  "data": {
    "timestamp": "2025-01-15T10:30:00Z",
    "cpu": {
      "percent": 45.2,
      "count": 8,
      "load_avg": [1.5, 1.2, 0.9]
    },
    "memory": {
      "total": 17179869184,
      "available": 8589934592,
      "percent": 50.0,
      "used": 8589934592
    },
    "swap": {
      "total": 8589934592,
      "used": 1073741824,
      "percent": 12.5
    },
    "disk": {
      "total": 500107862016,
      "used": 250053931008,
      "free": 250053931008,
      "percent": 50.0
    },
    "network": {
      "bytes_sent": 1073741824,
      "bytes_recv": 2147483648,
      "packets_sent": 1000000,
      "packets_recv": 2000000
    },
    "processes": [
      {
        "pid": 1234,
        "name": "Riven Backend",
        "cpu_percent": 5.2,
        "memory_percent": 2.1,
        "memory_rss": 134217728
      }
    ],
    "boot_time": "2025-01-01T00:00:00Z"
  }
}

items.title: History message format
items.text:
Sent once on connection when history=true:

{
  "type": "history",
  "items": [
    {
      "timestamp": "2025-01-15T10:29:00Z",
      "cpu": { "percent": 44.1 },
      "memory": { "percent": 49.5 }
    },
    {
      "timestamp": "2025-01-15T10:29:05Z",
      "cpu": { "percent": 45.0 },
      "memory": { "percent": 49.8 }
    }
  ],
  "bucket_seconds": 5
}

items.title: Metric field descriptions
items.text: Category Field Description CPU percent Overall CPU usage percentage CPU count Number of CPU cores CPU load_avg 1, 5, 15 minute load averages Memory total Total RAM in bytes Memory available Available RAM in bytes Memory percent Memory usage percentage Disk total Total disk space in bytes Disk used Used disk space in bytes Disk percent Disk usage percentage Network bytes_sent Total bytes sent Network bytes_recv Total bytes received

items.title: Endpoint
items.text:
/ws/logs

Streams real-time log output from all DUMB-managed services.

items.title: Query parameters
items.text: Parameter Type Default Description token string - JWT access token (required if auth enabled)

items.title: Connection example
items.text:
const ws = new WebSocket('ws://localhost:8000/ws/logs?token=...');

ws.onmessage = (event) => {
  // Each message is a log line
  appendToLogViewer(event.data);
};

items.title: Message format
items.text:
Log messages are sent as plain text lines:

Apr 12, 2025 10:04:01 - INFO - Riven Backend started
Apr 12, 2025 10:04:02 - DEBUG - Processing request...
Apr 12, 2025 10:04:03 - ERROR - Connection failed: timeout

Client-side filtering

The server broadcasts all logs to connected clients. Filtering by process name, log level, or search term should be implemented client-side.

items.title: Ping/pong heartbeat
items.text:
Send a ping message to keep the connection alive:

{"type": "ping"}

Response:

pong

items.title: Reconnection strategy
items.text:
WebSocket connections may drop due to network issues. Implement automatic reconnection:

function connectWebSocket() {
  const ws = new WebSocket('ws://localhost:8000/ws/status?token=...');

  ws.onclose = () => {
    // Reconnect after delay with exponential backoff
    setTimeout(connectWebSocket, Math.min(reconnectDelay * 2, 10000));
  };

  ws.onerror = (error) => {
    console.error('WebSocket error:', error);
    ws.close();
  };
}

items.title: Multiple connections
items.text:
The frontend typically maintains separate connections for each WebSocket endpoint:

  • One connection for /ws/status (service monitoring)
  • One connection for /ws/metrics (system charts)
  • One connection for /ws/logs (log viewer, when active)

items.title: Connection errors
items.text: Close Code Reason 1000 Normal closure 1001 Server going away (shutdown) 1006 Abnormal closure (network error) 4001 Authentication required 4003 Invalid or expired token

items.title: Handling authentication errors
items.text:
ws.onclose = (event) => {
  if (event.code === 4001 || event.code === 4003) {
    // Token expired or invalid - refresh and reconnect
    refreshToken().then(() => connectWebSocket());
  }
};

items.title: Python client example
items.text:
import asyncio
import websockets
import json

async def monitor_status():
    uri = "ws://localhost:8000/ws/status?interval=2&health=true"

    async with websockets.connect(uri) as websocket:
        async for message in websocket:
            data = json.loads(message)
            for process in data.get("processes", []):
                print(f"{process['process_name']}: {process['status']}")

asyncio.run(monitor_status())

items.title: Related pages
items.text:
• Authentication API - Token management for WebSocket auth
  • Logs API - REST endpoint for historical log access
  • Process Management API - Service control endpoints
  • DUMB Frontend - Web interface using these endpoints

items.title: WebSocket Logs API
items.text: The WebSocket Logs API provides a real-time streaming interface for receiving logs from all DUMB-managed subprocesses. It is primarily used by the DUMB Frontend to power the live log viewer.

items.title: WebSocket Endpoint
items.text:
/ws/logs

Connect to this endpoint using a WebSocket client (e.g., browser or Python client) to receive log lines as plain text.

items.title: Message Format
items.text:
Each log entry is sent as a plain text line formatted by DUMB‚Äôs logger, for example:

Apr 12, 2025 10:04:01 - INFO - Riven Backend started

Filtering Logs (Client-side)

The server pushes all logs to connected clients. It is up to the client to filter based on:

  • Process Name
  • Log Level
  • Search Term

The DUMB Frontend implements dropdowns and search bars for this purpose.

Connection Behavior

  • The server broadcasts logs to all connected WebSocket clients.
  • If the connection is dropped, reconnect using /ws/logs.
  • Log history is not buffered, so missed logs are not resent on reconnect.
  • Sending {"type":"ping"} will return pong.

items.title: Example (Python Client)
items.text:
import websockets
import asyncio
import json

async def consume_logs():
    uri = "ws://localhost:8000/ws/logs"
    async with websockets.connect(uri) as websocket:
        async for message in websocket:
            print(message)

asyncio.run(consume_logs())

items.title: Related Modules
items.text:
• websocket_logs.py
  • Logs API for historical log file access
  • Frontend Log Viewer

items.title: Architecture overview
items.text: This section explains how DUMB is structured, how services are orchestrated, and how the frontend, backend, and proxy layers interact.

items.title: System overview
items.text:
DUMB bundles a FastAPI backend, a Nuxt 4 frontend, and a set of managed services (core, dependent, and optional). The backend owns configuration, process lifecycle, and update automation. The frontend surfaces status, logs, and configuration controls.

flowchart TD
    U([User browser])
    FE[DUMB frontend]
    API[DUMB API]
    PH[Process handler]
    CFG[Config manager]
    SVC[Managed services]
    VOLS[(Storage mounts)]
    TR["Traefik (optional)"]

    U ==> FE
    FE ==> API
    API ==> PH
    API ==> CFG
    PH ==> SVC
    SVC ==> VOLS
    FE -.-> TR
    TR ==> SVC

items.title: Core building blocks
items.text: Component Responsibility DUMB API REST + WebSocket endpoints, config and process control Process handler Starts/stops services, monitors status, orchestrates updates Config manager Loads dumb_config.json, validates, persists changes Auto-update Fetches releases/branches and applies updates per service Auto-restart Monitors health and restarts services when needed Frontend UI for service status, logs, configuration, and onboarding Traefik Unified service UI routing (optional)

items.title: Storage and mounts
items.text:
Most services store state under /data, /config, or service-specific directories (for example /riven, /cli_debrid, /decypharr, /nzbdav). Media access is typically provided via /mnt/debrid, with symlink folders exposed for curated libraries.

Mount propagation

When Arr services or media servers run outside the DUMB container, ensure mount propagation (rshared/rslave) is configured so symlinks and rclone mounts stay consistent.

items.title: Networking and proxying
items.text:
DUMB exposes the frontend and API directly, while Traefik can be enabled to consolidate access to service UIs under a single port and path-based routing.

Traefik is optional

You can access service UIs directly on their ports, or enable Traefik to route everything under a single endpoint.

items.title: Configuration lifecycle
items.text:
1. DUMB loads dumb_config.json on startup.
  2. The API and process handler apply config changes.
  3. Service-specific setup hooks patch configs and directories.
  4. The frontend reflects status and logs in real time.

items.title: Related pages
items.text:
• Backend architecture
  • Frontend architecture
  • Traefik proxy

items.title: Backend architecture
items.text: The DUMB backend is a FastAPI service that manages configuration, process lifecycle, and real-time updates. It is the control plane for all managed services.

items.title: Core components
items.text: Component Responsibility FastAPI app HTTP API surface and WebSocket hubs Routers /auth, /process, /config, /logs, /metrics, /ws/* Config manager Reads/writes dumb_config.json and service settings Process handler Starts/stops services and reports status Auto-update Downloads releases/branches, runs setup, restarts services Auto-restart Monitors service health and applies backoff Metrics Collects system and service telemetry

items.title: Control plane flow
items.text:
%%{ init: { "flowchart": { "curve": "basis" } } }%%
flowchart TD
    UI([Frontend actions])
    API[DUMB API]
    CFG[Config manager]
    PH[Process handler]
    SVC[Managed services]
    WS[(WebSocket streams)]
    LOG[(Logs + metrics)]

    UI ==> API
    API ==> CFG
    API ==> PH
    PH ==> SVC
    SVC ==> LOG
    LOG ==> WS
    WS ==> UI

items.title: Request flow
items.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant UI as Frontend
    participant API as DUMB API
    participant CFG as Config manager
    participant PH as Process handler
    UI->>API: Update config / start service
    API->>CFG: Validate + persist config
    API->>PH: Start/stop/restart
    PH-->>API: Status + logs
    API-->>UI: WebSocket updates

items.title: Configuration pipeline
items.text:
1. The API validates configuration updates.
  2. Service setup hooks patch service-specific configs (for example Decypharr or NzbDAV).
  3. The process handler applies changes and updates status.
  4. WebSocket channels broadcast logs and state.

Config ownership

The backend is the source of truth for dumb_config.json. Manual edits are allowed, but should be followed by a reload or restart so the process handler picks up changes.

items.title: Service orchestration
items.text:
Service lifecycle is centralized in the process handler, which:

  • Tracks enabled services and instances
  • Executes setup/install steps
  • Applies auto-update scheduling
  • Enforces shutdown ordering

items.title: WebSocket channels
items.text:
The backend exposes WebSocket endpoints for:

  • Service status updates
  • Log streaming
  • Metrics updates

These streams power the frontend‚Äôs real-time dashboard.

items.title: Related pages
items.text:
• API reference
  • Process management
  • Authentication

items.title: Frontend architecture
items.text: The DUMB frontend is a Nuxt 4 application that renders the dashboard, service controls, and embedded UIs. It communicates with the DUMB API for configuration, logs, metrics, and service status.

items.title: Key directories
items.text: Path Purpose pages/ Route-driven pages (dashboard, settings, onboarding) components/ Reusable UI components composables/ Shared logic and API hooks stores/ Pinia stores for app state services/ API clients and service abstractions layouts/ Layout templates

items.title: Data flow
items.text:
%%{ init: { "flowchart": { "curve": "basis" } } }%%
flowchart LR
    UI([Pages + components])
    ST[Pinia stores]
    API[API client]
    BE[[DUMB API]]
    WS[(WebSocket streams)]

    UI ==> ST
    ST ==> API
    API ==> BE
    BE ==> WS
    WS ==> ST

items.title: Embedded service UIs
items.text:
The frontend can embed service UIs in iframes when Traefik is enabled, keeping navigation and authentication within the DUMB experience.

Traefik paths

Embedded UIs use Traefik paths like http://<host>/radarr/ or http://<host>/sonarr/ when proxying is enabled.

items.title: Configuration UX
items.text:
Configuration editing is performed in the settings UI, which:

  • Reads service config from the API
  • Validates changes client-side where possible
  • Submits updates to the backend for persistence

items.title: Related pages
items.text:
• Frontend overview
  • Dashboard guide
  • Settings guide

items.title: Traefik proxy
items.text: Traefik provides optional reverse-proxy routing for service UIs. When enabled, it exposes a single entry point and maps services to path-based routes.

items.title: What Traefik does in DUMB
items.text:
• Builds dynamic routes for enabled services
  • Adds path prefixes for UI services (for example /sonarr/, /radarr/)
  • Supports embedded iframes in the frontend

items.title: Default access
items.text:
Component Default Traefik entrypoint http://<host>:18080/ DUMB API (Scalar) http://<host>/dumb_api_service/scalar DUMB Frontend http://<host>/dumb_frontend/

Path prefixes

Some services use explicit prefixes (for example Emby/Jellyfin use /web), which Traefik preserves.

items.title: How routes are generated
items.text: The backend generates Traefik config based on enabled services and their ports. Services with UIs are registered automatically when they are enabled in dumb_config.json.

items.title: Security considerations
items.text:
No built-in auth

Most service UIs do not require authentication. If you expose Traefik outside your LAN, add authentication and TLS at the proxy layer.

items.title: Related pages
items.text:
• Embedded UIs
  • Service ports

items.title: Deployment Overview
items.text:
DUMB can be deployed across a variety of platforms and environments. Whether you're using Docker, Portainer, Unraid, WSL2, or other systems like TrueNAS, Synology, or QNAP, this section will guide you through the available options to get DUMB up and running.

All deployment methods provide access to the same integrated services and configurations, with slight differences in how the container is started and managed.

Platform-Specific Instructions

Select your platform from the left navigation to view detailed, platform-specific deployment instructions. Each platform guide includes step-by-step setup instructions tailored to your environment.

items.title: System Requirements
items.text:
• Docker or Docker-compatible environment
  • Linux system (WSL on Windows when using rshared)
  • Minimum 2 vCPU, 2GB RAM, SSD recommended

Docker Desktop

Docker Desktop CANNOT be used to run DUMB when using rshared mount propagation.

Docker Desktop does not support the mount propagation required for rclone mounts.

See the deployment options to run DUMB on Windows through WSL2.

items.title: Required Credentials
items.text:
Service Required Info Debrid API Key (Real-Debrid) GitHub Token (if using the sponsored Zurg repo)

See Configuration ‚Üí Integration Tokens

items.title: Required Directories
items.text:
You'll need to bind mount the following volumes when running the container:

Container Mount Path Description /config Location for configuration files /log Location for logs /zurg/RD Location for Zurg RealDebrid active configuration /riven/backend/data Location for Riven Backend data /postgres_data Location for PostgreSQL databases /pgadmin/data Location for pgAdmin 4 data /zilean/app/data Location for Zilean data /plex_debrid/config Location for plex_debrid data /cli_debrid/data Location for cli_debrid data /phalanx_db/data Location for phalanx_db data /decypharr Location for decypharr data /plex Location for Plex Media Server data /mnt/debrid Location for raw debrid files/links and symlinks

/config

If a Zurg config.yml and/or Zurg app is placed here, it will be used to override the default configuration and/or app used at startup.

/mnt/debrid:rshared

The :rshared must be included in order to support mount propagation for rclone to the host when exposing the raw debrid files/links to an external container; e.g., the arrs or a media server.

:rshared is not required when using the default configuration leveraging the internal media server or when not utilizing Decypharr.

Configuration Requirements

All deployment methods rely on a valid and accessible dumb_config.json file for configuring services.

It is strongly recommended to bind-mount a local config directory to persist user data.

Example Volume Mount

dumb:
  image: iampuid0/dumb:latest
  volumes:
    - ./config:/config

For more about configuring services, see the Configuration page.

items.title: Related Pages
items.text:
• Service Overview
  • Features

items.title: Deploy with Docker
items.text:
This guide assumes you have never used Docker before. It walks through what Docker is, how Docker Compose works, how to install Docker on Ubuntu, and how to deploy DUMB cleanly with persistent storage.

Prefer a UI?

Portainer is a great option if you want a web UI for managing containers, logs, and volumes. If you want to deploy DUMB with Portainer Stacks, follow the Portainer deployment guide instead.

items.title: Prerequisites
items.text:
Before you begin, confirm you have:

  • A system running Ubuntu 20.04 or later
  • A non-root user with sudo privileges
  • An active internet connection
  • Access to a terminal

Avoid the Snap package

Do not install Docker via Snap. The Snap build often breaks networking, volume mounts, and socket permissions required by DUMB. Use the official Docker install method in this guide instead.

Windows users

If you're on Windows, use the Windows Setup Guide (Docker/WSL).

items.title: What Docker and Docker Compose do
items.text:
Docker runs applications inside containers, which are isolated environments that package the app and its dependencies. Docker Compose is a helper tool that starts one or more containers using a docker-compose.yml file.

For DUMB, Compose:

  • Pulls the DUMB image from a registry
  • Creates a container with your settings
  • Mounts your local folders so configs and logs persist
  • Exposes ports so you can reach the UI and API

items.title: Install Docker (official method)
items.text:
1. Download the official installer:

    curl -fsSL https://get.docker.com -o get-docker.sh

  2. Run it and follow any prompts:

    sh get-docker.sh

WSL detected

If the installer reports WSL, follow the Windows Setup Guide (Docker/WSL).

items.title: Install Docker on other Linux distributions
items.text:
If you are not on Ubuntu, use the official Docker Engine instructions for your OS:

  • Debian: https://docs.docker.com/engine/install/debian/
  • Fedora: https://docs.docker.com/engine/install/fedora/
  • RHEL/CentOS: https://docs.docker.com/engine/install/centos/
  • Arch: https://docs.docker.com/engine/install/archlinux/

Use the Docker Engine package (not Snap). Once installed, return to this guide and continue from Confirm Docker and Compose are installed.

items.title: Confirm Docker and Compose are installed
items.text:
1. Check the Docker version:

    docker --version

  2. Check Docker Compose version:

    docker compose version

Example output:

Docker version 26.1.4, build 5650f9b
Docker Compose version v2.24.2

items.title: Optional: allow non-root Docker usage
items.text:
By default, Docker commands require sudo. If you want to run Docker without sudo, add your user to the docker group.

sudo usermod -aG docker $USER

Log out and back in (or reboot) so group membership refreshes.

If you skip this step, keep using sudo for Docker commands.

items.title: Define the directory structure
items.text:
These folders store configs, logs, and data outside the container, so they survive upgrades and restarts.

  1. Create a workspace:

    cd ~
mkdir -p docker
cd docker

  2. Create DUMB directories:

    mkdir -p DUMB/config DUMB/log DUMB/data DUMB/mnt/debrid

Stopping here for Portainer

If you plan to deploy DUMB via Portainer Stacks, stop after creating the directory structure. You will paste the docker-compose.yml into Portainer and deploy it from there instead of running docker compose on the host.

items.title: Download and edit docker-compose.yml
items.text:
1. Download the latest Compose file:

    curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/I-am-PUID-0/DUMB/master/docker-compose.yml

  2. Replace the default path with your home directory:

    sed -i "s|/home/username/docker/DUMB|$HOME/docker/DUMB|g" docker-compose.yml

  3. Fill in TZ, PUID, and PGID:

    read -p "Enter your timezone [UTC]: " TZ && TZ=${TZ:-UTC} && \
sed -i \
  -e "s|TZ=|TZ=$TZ|" \
  -e "s|PUID=|PUID=$(id -u)|" \
  -e "s|PGID=|PGID=$(id -g)|" \
  docker-compose.yml

Timezone format

Use a region format like America/New_York or Europe/London.

items.title: Start DUMB with Docker Compose
items.text:
Run the container in detached mode:

sudo docker compose up -d

Example output:

[+] Running 2/2
 Container DUMB  Started
 Network docker_default  Created

The container now runs in the background.

items.title: Access the UI
items.text:
By default:

  • DUMB Frontend: http://<host>:3005
  • DUMB API: http://<host>:8000

If you do not see the UI:

  • Confirm the container is running: sudo docker ps
  • Check logs: sudo docker logs -f DUMB
  • Ensure ports are exposed in your docker-compose.yml
  • See Service ports

items.title: Expose ports for direct UI access
items.text:
Docker only exposes ports you explicitly map in your docker-compose.yml. If a UI is not reachable, it usually means the port is not mapped.

Example: expose the DUMB frontend and API.

services:
  DUMB:
    ports:
      - "3005:3005"
      - "8000:8000"

Example: expose an Arr service UI (Radarr).

services:
  DUMB:
    ports:
      - "7878:7878"

Reverse proxy or embedded UIs

If you use a reverse proxy (Traefik, Nginx, Caddy) or DUMB‚Äôs embedded UIs, you can avoid exposing every service port directly.

After updating ports, restart the stack:

sudo docker compose down
sudo docker compose up -d

items.title: Attach to the running container
items.text: sudo docker attach DUMB

items.title: Detach without stopping
items.text:
Press Ctrl + P then Ctrl + Q to detach and leave it running.

Avoid Ctrl+C

Ctrl+C stops the container if it is attached to your terminal.

items.title: View logs
items.text: sudo docker logs -f DUMB

items.title: Stop and remove the container
items.text: sudo docker compose down

items.title: Next steps
items.text:
• Continue setup in the DUMB Frontend
  • Review Configuration
  • Use Service ports to expose UIs as needed

items.title: Deploying DUMB with Portainer
items.text: Portainer provides a user-friendly web interface for managing Docker containers and stacks. This guide walks you through deploying Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge (DUMB) using Portainer's stack deployment feature.

items.title: Prerequisites
items.text:
Before you begin:

  • Docker must be installed and running
  • Portainer must be installed and running
  • Internet access (to pull the DUMB image)
  • Host directories prepared for persistent data storage

Avoid the Snap package

Do not install Docker via Snap. The Snap build often breaks networking, volume mounts, and socket permissions required by DUMB. Use the official Docker install method instead.

items.title: Install Docker (if needed)
items.text: If Docker is not installed yet, follow the Docker deployment guide up through Confirm Docker and Compose are installed.

items.title: Install Portainer (quick start)
items.text:
Use this if Portainer is not installed yet. It runs Portainer as a container.

docker volume create portainer_data
docker run -d \
  --name portainer \
  -p 9443:9443 \
  -p 9000:9000 \
  -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock \
  -v portainer_data:/data \
  --restart=always \
  portainer/portainer-ce:latest

Then open https://<host>:9443 and complete the setup wizard.

items.title: Prepare the directory structure
items.text:
Create folders for persistent config, logs, data, and mounts:

mkdir -p /home/$USER/docker/DUMB/config /home/$USER/docker/DUMB/log /home/$USER/docker/DUMB/data /home/$USER/docker/DUMB/mnt/debrid

Avoid ~ in Portainer stacks

Portainer does not reliably expand ~ in stack files. Use full paths such as /home/<user>/docker/DUMB.

items.title: Where to get the Compose file
items.text:
Pull the latest Compose file from GitHub:

curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/I-am-PUID-0/DUMB/master/docker-compose.yml

items.title: Edit paths and environment variables
items.text:
Update the Compose file before pasting it into Portainer:

  • Replace /home/username/docker/DUMB with your actual path (for example /home/<user>/docker/DUMB).
  • Set TZ to your timezone (for example America/New_York).
  • Set PUID and PGID to your user and group IDs.

Use this helper to patch the compose file:

read -p "Enter your DUMB base path [/home/$USER/docker/DUMB]: " DUMB_PATH
DUMB_PATH=${DUMB_PATH:-/home/$USER/docker/DUMB}
read -p "Enter your timezone [UTC]: " TZ
TZ=${TZ:-UTC}
PUID=$(id -u)
PGID=$(id -g)

sed -i \
  -e "s|/home/username/docker/DUMB|$DUMB_PATH|g" \
  -e "s|TZ=|TZ=$TZ|" \
  -e "s|PUID=|PUID=$PUID|" \
  -e "s|PGID=|PGID=$PGID|" \
  docker-compose.yml

items.title: Copy the Compose content for Portainer
items.text:
Print the file and copy it into Portainer‚Äôs Web editor:

cat docker-compose.yml

items.title: 1. Log into Portainer
items.text: Navigate to your Portainer instance (e.g., http://localhost:9000, or https://localhost:9443) and log in.

items.title: 2. Navigate to Stacks
items.text: Click on Stacks in the left sidebar.

items.title: 3. Click "Add Stack"
items.text: Click the + Add stack button at the top-right.

items.title: 4. Configure the stack
items.text:
Enter the following:

  • Name: dumb
  • Build method: Select Web editor
  • Web editor: Paste the DUMB docker-compose content

items.title: 5. Deploy the stack
items.text: Click Deploy the stack to launch DUMB.

items.title: That‚Äôs it!
items.text:
Once deployed, DUMB will initialize and make its services available at their respective ports (e.g., DUMB Frontend at :3005, API at :8000, etc.).

You can now manage DUMB entirely through the DUMB Frontend, or explore the Configuration docs to adjust settings as needed.

items.title: Expose ports (direct access)
items.text:
Portainer only exposes the ports listed in your Compose file. If a UI is not reachable, confirm the port mapping exists in the stack.

Example:

ports:
  - "3005:3005" # DUMB Frontend
  - "8000:8000" # DUMB API
  - "7878:7878" # Radarr

After editing ports, click Update the stack to redeploy.

Reverse proxy or embedded UIs

If you use a reverse proxy (Traefik, Nginx, Caddy) or DUMB‚Äôs embedded UIs, you can avoid exposing every service port directly.

items.title: Viewing Logs for DUMB
items.text:
Once your stack is deployed, you can view logs for the DUMB container:

  1. Navigate to Containers from the left sidebar.
  2. Click on the DUMB container name.
  3. Go to the Logs tab.
  4. Logs will stream live by default. You can scroll or refresh for updates.

This is helpful for debugging service startup or checking configuration issues.

items.title: Attach to the Container
items.text:
To view live output or run interactive commands:

  1. From the Containers page, click on the DUMB container.
  2. Click the Attach Console button
  3. Choose a shell (e.g., sh, bash, or /venv/bin/python) and click Connect.

Use this for tasks like inspecting running processes, modifying configs, or testing tools inside the container.

items.title: Console Access
items.text:
You can also use the Console option to access the container shell:

  1. From the Containers tab, click on DUMB.
  2. Click the Console tab.
  3. Choose the shell you wish to run.
  4. Click Connect.

Great for quick inspection or administrative tasks inside the container.

items.title: Update the stack
items.text:
To update DUMB:

  1. Open Stacks
  2. Click the dumb stack
  3. Click Edit
  4. Replace the Compose content with the latest version
  5. Click Update the stack

If you have auto-update enabled in DUMB, you may not need to redeploy the stack for application updates, but you should still update the Compose file if it changes.

items.title: Deploying DUMB on Proxmox (LXC Container)
items.text: This guide will walk you through deploying DUMB inside a lightweight Ubuntu-based LXC container on Proxmox VE.

items.title: Prerequisites
items.text:
• Proxmox VE installed
  • Internet access on the host
  • Basic knowledge of Proxmox shell and web UI

items.title: Create an Ubuntu LXC Container
items.text:
You can automate Ubuntu LXC creation with the following community script:

bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/community-scripts/ProxmoxVE/main/ct/ubuntu.sh)"

This will download and install an Ubuntu container in Proxmox.

items.title: LXC Configuration for Docker + Fuse Support
items.text: To ensure DUMB works correctly inside your LXC container (especially with Docker, rclone, and bind mounts), you‚Äôll need to update both the container config, the Proxmox host, and optionally configure persistence across reboots.

items.title: Update the LXC Config File
items.text:
<CTID> is the container ID.

  1. Stop the container:

    pct stop <CTID>

  2. Edit the container config file:

    nano /etc/pve/lxc/<CTID>.conf

  3. Ensure the following lines are present:

    features: nesting=1
lxc.cgroup2.devices.allow: a
lxc.cgroup2.devices.allow: c 10:229 rwm
lxc.mount.entry: /dev/fuse dev/fuse none bind,create=file
lxc.mount.entry: /mnt/docker-mounts mnt/docker-mounts none bind,create=dir
lxc.apparmor.profile: unconfined

Note

Don't restart the LXC until the below sections have been completed.

items.title: Configure Host Bind Mount
items.text:
1. On the Proxmox host, create the mount target and bind it:

    mkdir -p /mnt/docker-mounts
mount --bind /mnt/docker-mounts /mnt/docker-mounts
mount --make-rshared /mnt/docker-mounts

items.title: Make the Mount Persistent (Recommended)
items.text: This ensures the bind mount is restored after reboots.

items.title: Option A: Use /etc/fstab and manually set the mount propagation after reboot
items.text:
1. Open the file:

    nano /etc/fstab

  2. Add this line at the bottom:

    /mnt/docker-mounts /mnt/docker-mounts none bind 0 0

  3. After a reboot, paste the following 

    mount --make-rshared /mnt/docker-mounts

items.title: Option B: Automate rshared with systemd (Optional, but recommended)
items.text:
This ensures the bind mount propagation is set after reboots.

To persist the rshared behavior across boots:

  1. Create a new service file:

    nano /etc/systemd/system/mnt-docker-mounts-rshared.service

  2. Paste the following:

    [Unit]
Description=Make /mnt/docker-mounts rshared
After=local-fs.target
RequiresMountsFor=/mnt/docker-mounts

[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/bin/mount --make-rshared /mnt/docker-mounts
RemainAfterExit=true

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

  3. Reload systemd and enable the service:

    systemctl daemon-reexec
systemctl enable --now mnt-docker-mounts-rshared.service

items.title: Add and Configure a User inside the LXC (Required)
items.text:
DUMB must be ran as any user other than root

  1. Start/Restart the container:

    pct start <CTID>

    systemctl restart pve-container@<CTID> may need to be used for changes to apply

  2. If not already created in the LXC, add a user (ubuntu) and configure passwordless sudo:

    adduser ubuntu
usermod -aG sudo ubuntu

  3. Enable passwordless sudo (Optional): 

    echo "ubuntu ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD:ALL" > /etc/sudoers.d/ubuntu
chmod 440 /etc/sudoers.d/ubuntu

    Tip

    To find the UID and GID (needed for PUID and PGID in your DUMB config): 

    id ubuntu

    Example output: 

    uid=1000(ubuntu) gid=1000(ubuntu)

    Use these values in your dumb_config.json or docker-compose: 

    "puid": 1000,
"pgid": 1000,

items.title: Define the Directory Structure inside the LXC
items.text:
Note

If you already have a directory structure you'd like to use, then you can skip this step.

  1. Switch to the ubuntu user:

    su ubuntu

  2. Create a directory for docker in your user directory and change directories to docker. 

    cd ~ && mkdir docker && cd docker

  3. Create the DUMB directories. 

    mkdir -p DUMB/config DUMB/log DUMB/Zurg/RD DUMB/Riven/data DUMB/Riven/mnt DUMB/PostgreSQL/data DUMB/pgAdmin4/data DUMB/Zilean/data

items.title: Install Docker inside the LXC
items.text:
1. Run the official Docker install script:

    curl -fsSL https://get.docker.com -o get-docker.sh
sh get-docker.sh

  2. After installing Docker, verify it: 

    docker --version
docker compose version

  3. Add your user to the docker group: 

    sudo groupadd docker
sudo usermod -aG docker $USER

items.title: Install Portainer inside the LXC (Optional)
items.text:
If you want to manage Docker visually via Portainer:

  1. Create the Portainer data volume: 

    docker volume create portainer_data

  2. Start the Portainer container:

    docker run -d \
-p 8000:8000 \
-p 9443:9443 \
--name portainer \
--restart=always \
-v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock \
-v portainer_data:/data \
portainer/portainer-ce:latest

You can now manage Docker containers via the browser at: https://<ip>:9443

Note

On the first run of Portainer, you need to access the Web UI quickly to create your initial administrator user, which is crucial for accessing and managing your Docker environment.

Tip
