If you can't access the UI after the initial setup, ensure the Portainer container is running and that the correct port is open. You might need to restart the container if it timed out.

For more, see the Portainer Deployment Guide.

items.title: Update Docker Bind Mount (Important)
items.text:
When launching DUMB or your media server, make sure the following mount is used:

Replace: 

- /home/username/docker/DUMB/Zurg/mnt:/data:shared

With: 

- /mnt/docker-mounts:/data:rshared

This ensures proper visibility between zurg, rclone, and your media server inside the LXC container.

items.title: Next Steps
items.text:
Now that Docker (and optionally Portainer) are installed, continue with:

  • Deploy DUMB via Docker Compose
  • Configure your stack with Portainer

items.title: Deploying DUMB on unRAID
items.text: This guide will walk you through deploying Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge (DUMB) on unRAID using the Community Applications plugin and Docker.

items.title: Prerequisites
items.text:
Before proceeding, ensure you have the following:

  • A running unRAID server with Docker enabled.
  • The Community Applications plugin installed.
  • At least one unRAID share for persistent storage (e.g., /mnt/user/appdata/DUMB).
  • An understanding of basic Docker container and volume mapping in unRAID.

Optional but recommended:

  • Installed media server such as Plex, Jellyfin, or Emby.
  • A valid Plex Token (if using Plex integration).

items.title: 1. Install the DUMB Template
items.text:
• Navigate to the Apps tab in unRAID.
  • Search for DUMB and select the Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge template.
  • Click Install.

items.title: 2. Path and Variable Configuration
items.text: Ensure your paths and environment variables are set correctly: - Mount all relevant paths (e.g., /mnt, /config, /cache) to valid unRAID shares. - Set your PUID to 99 and PGID to 100 (used for nobody:users on unRAID). - Set your timezone (TZ) appropriately (e.g., America/New_York).

items.title: 3. Fix Permissions (First-Time Only)
items.text: Docker on unRAID may create directories as root, causing permission issues. Fix this using the following method:

items.title: Terminal Method:
items.text: chown -R 99:100 /mnt/user/appdata/DUMB

items.title: WebUI Method:
items.text:
1. Go to Shares > locate your DUMB share.
  2. Click the + to expand.
  3. Under Owner, set to nobody (user ID 99).

items.title: 4. Start the Container
items.text:
• Click Start in the Docker tab.
  • Open the Logs tab to confirm successful startup.
  • Look for a confirmation message that riven frontend has started.

items.title: Matching Paths in Plex, Jellyfin, Emby
items.text:
Your Media Server (Plex, Jellyfin, or Emby) must have the same paths as DUMB:

  • DUMB mounts:
  • /mnt (contains both Riven and Zurg content)
  • In your media server:
  • Mount /mnt to /mnt as well.
  • Only add the Riven path (e.g., /mnt/movies, /mnt/shows) as libraries.

Do NOT add /data or Zurg‚Äôs full rclone mount as libraries. Use only the Riven symlinked content.

items.title: Example Screenshots
items.text:
• DUMB Docker setup:
  • Plex Docker container setup:
  • Plex UI Library paths:

items.title: Plex Token Setup
items.text:
To enable features like watchlist syncing, you may need your Plex token:

  1. Visit https://plex.tv, login.
  2. Open any item > click the 3 dots > View XML.
  3. At the end of the URL, copy the value after Plex-Token=.

items.title: Advanced Tools
items.text:
To troubleshoot permissions or inspect mounts: 

docker exec -w /mnt/movies dumb ls -Rl
To enter the container interactively: 
docker exec -it dumb sh
Install Midnight Commander (optional): 
apk add mc && mc

items.title: Jellyfin and Emby Notes
items.text:
Both Jellyfin and Emby can work with DUMB:

  • Map /mnt into the containers.
  • Add only the Riven subpaths (/mnt/movies, /mnt/shows) as libraries.

items.title: Troubleshooting
items.text:
• Check logs via Docker tab > select DUMB > Logs.
  • Use docker exec or Midnight Commander to inspect file/folder structure.
  • Common issues:
  • Wrong PUID/PGID
  • Paths not matching between DUMB and your media server
  • Invalid Plex token

items.title: Deploying DUMB on Windows Setup Guide (Docker/WSL)
items.text:
Docker Desktop

Ensure that Docker Desktop is not installed; if so, uninstall and reboot before proceeding.

This guide will walk you through setting up DUMB on a Windows system using a lightweight Docker + WSL2 setup, without relying on Docker Desktop.

items.title: WSL Install
items.text:
1. From the Microsoft Store, install Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)

  2. From the Microsoft Store, install Ubuntu 22.04 LTS

  3. Follow the setup to create your Ubuntu username and password

  4. From a Windows Command Prompt, paste the following:

    cd C:\WINDOWS\system32

  5. Then set Ubuntu 22.04 as the default distro:

    wsl --setdefault Ubuntu-22.04

  6. From the Windows app menu, start Ubuntu 22.04, then paste the following inside the terminal:

    Note

    This step is only required if sharing the mount outside of the container - e.g., to another media server, etc. 

    sudo apt update
sudo apt upgrade -y
sudo mount --make-rshared /

    Note

    sudo mount --make-rshared / does not persist after reboots. You‚Äôll need to run it each time WSL2 or Windows is restarted.

    Alternatively, see the Ubuntu systemd service guide to automate this at startup.

items.title: Docker Install
items.text:
1. Follow the official Docker Engine install guide for Ubuntu

  2. Once Docker is installed, you can either:

    • Use the standard Docker CLI to create the container
    • Or follow the Docker Deployment or Portainer Deployment guides for predefined setups

items.title: Accessing the Mount on Windows
items.text:
Note

These steps are only required if sharing the mount outside of the container - e.g., to another media server, etc.

  1. From the Ubuntu terminal, open File Explorer in the current directory:

    explorer.exe .

  2. A new File Explorer window will appear ‚Äî you‚Äôre now inside the Ubuntu file system

  3. Navigate to the mount location and copy the full path from the Explorer address bar

  4. In another File Explorer window:

    • Click This PC
    • Right-click in the blank space and select Add a network location

  5. In the popup:

    • Click Next twice
    • Paste the WSL path you copied

  6. Complete the remaining prompts to finalize the mount

items.title: Mirrored Mode Networking
items.text: Starting with Windows 11 22H2, WSL2 supports a new networking mode called mirrored networking, which improves compatibility and unlocks several new features by mirroring Windows' network interfaces into Linux.

items.title: Benefits of Mirrored Networking
items.text:
• Full IPv6 support
  • Access Windows services from WSL using 127.0.0.1
  • Improved VPN support (VPNs work in both Windows and WSL)
  • Multicast compatibility
  • Reach WSL directly from your local LAN

items.title: Enabling Mirrored Mode
items.text:
1. Open (or create) the .wslconfig file in your Windows home directory:

    notepad $env:USERPROFILE\.wslconfig

  2. Add the following section:

    [wsl2]
networkingMode=mirrored

  3. Restart WSL for the changes to take effect:

    wsl --shutdown

    Then restart your distro from the Windows menu or run:

    wsl

items.title: Additional Notes
items.text:
• You can combine this with autoProxy=true if you're using a proxy.
  • This setting applies globally across all WSL2 instances.

items.title: Extra Credit
items.text:
If you want to manage Docker visually via Portainer:

  1. Create the Portainer data volume: 

    docker volume create portainer_data

  2. Start the Portainer container:

    docker run -d \
-p 8000:8000 \
-p 9443:9443 \
--name portainer \
--restart=always \
-v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock \
-v portainer_data:/data \
portainer/portainer-ce:latest

You can now manage Docker containers via the browser at: https://<ip>:9443

Note

On the first run of Portainer, you need to access the Web UI quickly to create your initial administrator user, which is crucial for accessing and managing your Docker environment.

Tip

If you can't access the UI after the initial setup, ensure the Portainer container is running and that the correct port is open. You might need to restart the container if it timed out.

For more, see the Portainer Deployment Guide.

Now you‚Äôre ready to run DUMB inside WSL2 with full Docker support ‚Äî no Docker Desktop required!

items.title: Authentication FAQ
items.text: Common questions and troubleshooting for DUMB's authentication system.

items.title: Do I need to enable authentication?
items.text:
Authentication is optional. It's recommended if:

  • DUMB is accessible from outside your local network
  • Multiple users access the system
  • You want to control who can start/stop services

You can skip authentication for local/trusted environments.

items.title: How do I create the first user account?
items.text:
When DUMB starts with no users:

  1. Navigate to the DUMB frontend
  2. You'll be redirected to /setup
  3. Enter a username and password
  4. Click Create Account

items.title: Can I change my password?
items.text:
Currently, password changes require:

  1. Deleting the existing user
  2. Creating a new user with the same username

Future feature

Password change functionality may be added in future updates.

items.title: How many users can I create?
items.text: There's no hard limit on the number of user accounts. Create as many as needed for your use case.

items.title: "Invalid credentials" error
items.text:
• Check username - Usernames are case-sensitive
  • Verify password - Passwords are also case-sensitive
  • Account status - Check if the user is disabled in Settings

items.title: "User account is disabled" error
items.text: An administrator has disabled your account. Contact an admin to re-enable it via Settings User Management.

items.title: Session expires too quickly
items.text:
Access tokens expire after 60 minutes by default. If you're experiencing frequent logouts:

  • Check if Remember Me was selected during login
  • Without Remember Me, tokens are stored in session storage and cleared when the browser closes
  • With Remember Me, tokens persist in local storage

items.title: Browser shows login page but I was logged in
items.text:
• Your access token may have expired
  • The frontend should automatically refresh - wait a moment
  • If it persists, clear browser storage and log in again
  • Check if authentication was recently disabled/re-enabled

items.title: How do I disable a user without deleting them?
items.text:
1. Go to Settings User Management
  2. Find the user
  3. Click the disable button

Disabled users cannot log in but their account remains for re-enabling later.

items.title: "Cannot disable the last active user" error
items.text:
DUMB prevents disabling or deleting the last non-disabled user to avoid lockouts. To disable this user:

  1. Create another user account first
  2. Then disable the original user

items.title: How do I delete a user?
items.text:
1. Go to Settings User Management
  2. Find the user
  3. Click the delete button
  4. Confirm the deletion

Permanent action

Deleted users cannot be recovered. Create a new account if needed.

items.title: I forgot my password - how do I reset it?
items.text:
DUMB doesn't have a password reset feature. To recover access:

  1. Stop the DUMB container
  2. Edit /config/users.json
  3. Set "auth_enabled": false
  4. Start the container
  5. Access DUMB and create a new user
  6. Re-enable authentication

items.title: I deleted all users and can't log in
items.text: Follow the lockout recovery steps above to disable authentication, then create a new user.

items.title: The users.json file is corrupted
items.text:
Replace it with a minimal valid file:

{
  "version": 2,
  "jwt_secret": "",
  "auth_enabled": false,
  "setup_skipped": false,
  "users": []
}

Then restart DUMB and go through setup again. A new JWT secret will be generated automatically.

items.title: How long do tokens last?
items.text: Token Type Lifetime Access Token 60 minutes Refresh Token 30 days

items.title: How do I authenticate API requests?
items.text:
Include the access token in the Authorization header:

curl -H "Authorization: Bearer <your_token>" http://localhost:8000/api/...

items.title: How do I authenticate WebSocket connections?
items.text:
Pass the token as a query parameter:

ws://localhost:8000/ws/status?token=<your_token>

items.title: My API calls return 401 Unauthorized
items.text:
• Verify the token is included in the Authorization header
  • Check if the token has expired
  • Ensure the format is Bearer <token> (with space)
  • Try getting a new token via login

items.title: Where are passwords stored?
items.text: Passwords are hashed using bcrypt and stored in /config/users.json. The original password is never stored.

items.title: Is the JWT secret secure?
items.text: The JWT secret is auto-generated when the first user is created. It's stored in /config/users.json and should be kept confidential.

items.title: Can I use DUMB without HTTPS?
items.text:
Yes, but authentication tokens will be transmitted in plain text. For production deployments exposed to the internet:

  • Use a reverse proxy with HTTPS
  • Or deploy behind a VPN

items.title: Should I disable authentication for local use?
items.text: For truly local/isolated environments (e.g., home lab with no internet exposure), disabling authentication simplifies access. However, if anyone on your network can reach DUMB, consider keeping authentication enabled.

items.title: Related pages
items.text:
• Authentication Feature Guide
  • Authentication API
  • DUMB FAQ

items.title: DUMB FAQ
items.text: Below are some common questions and solutions related to DUMB.

items.title: Does the DUMB image have the latest version of x
items.text:
The GitHub repo for DUMB use many continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) workflows to ensure proper building, reporting, and updating of the images.

For example, the Check for New Release Tags workflow is automated to run every three hours and check for updates to the various services/projects utilized in DUMB. If an update is found, the Docker Image CI workflow is called to build a new image with the latest services.

items.title: What versions are in the latest DUMB image
items.text:
Similar to the above question, and the answer is usually the latest; however, if there has been a recent release and the Check for New Release Tags workflow has not run yet, then there my be disparity.

To check, click on one of the Docker Image CI jobs to see the Build Summary

Example Build Summary below:

items.title: How do I enable authentication?
items.text:
Authentication can be enabled during the first-time setup or later via Settings:

  1. Navigate to Settings in the sidebar
  2. Find the Authentication section
  3. Click Enable Authentication
  4. If no users exist, create an admin account

See the Authentication Guide for details.

items.title: I'm locked out of DUMB - how do I reset authentication?
items.text:
If you cannot access your account:

  1. Stop the DUMB container
  2. Edit /config/users.json
  3. Set "auth_enabled": false
  4. Restart the container
  5. Access the dashboard and create a new user

items.title: Why do I get "Invalid credentials" when logging in?
items.text:
• Usernames are case-sensitive
  • Verify the password is correct
  • Check if your user account is disabled in Settings User Management

items.title: My session keeps expiring - what's wrong?
items.text:
• Access tokens expire after 60 minutes by default
  • The frontend should automatically refresh tokens
  • If issues persist, clear browser storage and log in again
  • Check if "Remember Me" was checked during login

items.title: Dashboard status is not updating in real-time
items.text:
1. Check the WebSocket connection indicator in the header
  2. Verify your browser supports WebSocket connections
  3. Check for network/firewall issues blocking WebSocket
  4. Try refreshing the page to reconnect

items.title: Metrics page shows "Disconnected"
items.text:
• The metrics WebSocket may have dropped
  • The frontend will automatically reconnect
  • If it persists, check DUMB API logs for errors

items.title: How do I access service UIs?
items.text:
When embedded UIs are enabled, access services at:

http://<host>:18080/service/ui/<service_name>

Or access services directly on their native ports. See Embedded Service UIs.

items.title: A service keeps restarting - what should I do?
items.text:
1. Check the service logs for error messages
  2. Verify the service configuration is valid
  3. Check if dependencies are running
  4. Review auto-restart settings in the service config

See Auto-restart for more information.

items.title: General FAQ
items.text: Below are some common questions and solutions related to DUMB that apply across multiple services or the platform as a whole.

items.title: Will DUMB use a lot of storage space?
items.text:
That depends on how you configure it. Most services (like Zurg and Rclone) operate by streaming content from the debrid service, so very little is permanently stored on your local system ‚Äî unless you're using rclone with VFS caching enabled.

VFS Cache Management

If you're using VFS cache (recommended for Plex), ensure that the cache size is managed appropriately. See the rclone configuration for more.

items.title: Do I need to install every service?
items.text:
No ‚Äî DUMB is modular. You can enable or disable services in dumb_config.json under each service section.

Service Types

Some core services (like riven_backend, cli_debrid, etc.) provide core functionality and have required dependent services (like zurg, rclone, postgres, etc.), but others (like pgadmin) are optional service tools to help you manage your setup.

items.title: Can I run DUMB offline?
items.text:
Internet Required

Most DUMB services interact with external APIs (e.g., Real-Debrid, Plex, Trakt, TMDB, etc.), so internet access is required for normal operation. However, local database tools (e.g., pgAdmin) and UIs may still function offline for inspection.

items.title: What happens when I update DUMB?
items.text:
The image maintained for DUMB is automatically updated when one of the embedded services (like riven_backend, cli_debrid, etc.) have a new release available; thus, reducing the need to update to the latest release inside the container. For more info, see the DUMB FAQ regarding finding what versions are built into the image.

Alternatively, DUMB also includes auto-update functionality for most services. Depending on your configuration (auto_update and auto_update_interval), the system will check for new versions of services like Zurg, Riven, Zilean, etc.

You can configure update frequency and behavior in each service‚Äôs section of dumb_config.json.

items.title: Is DUMB secure?
items.text:
DUMB is intended to run on your local or private server. Most services are, by default, bound to 127.0.0.1 and not exposed publicly unless explicitly configured by exposing ports in the Docker compose or changing the bound address.

Security Considerations

Most of the web-based UIs and APIs lack any form of authentication.

If you're exposing services externally (e.g., via Traefik or NGINX), consider using authentication layers like OAuth2, HTTPS, and firewalls.

items.title: Can I use my own custom version of a service?
items.text: Yes ‚Äî you can point most services to a custom branch or fork by editing the repo_owner, repo_name, branch, or release_version in its config section in dumb_config.json. This is especially useful if you are testing development builds or your own patches.

items.title: Can I back up my DUMB setup?
items.text:
Absolutely. The most important files to back up are:

  • dumb_config.json
  • Any data directories (e.g., /riven/backend/data, /zilean/app/data, /pgadmin/data, postgres_data, plex, etc)

Backup Strategy

Regularly backing these up allows you to quickly restore your environment.

Exclude Mounted Paths

Be sure to exclude any mounted paths (e.g., /mnt/debrid) when backing up. Otherwise, you'll unintentionally download and archive the entire contents of your debrid services, which can be massive and unnecessary.

Don't believe me? Just ask Mr. Krabs.

items.title: Can I monitor the system?
items.text: Yes ‚Äî the DUMB Frontend shows real-time logs, service logs, service status, and allows interactive config management. You can also access logs from the filesystem or via the DUMB API (see API docs).

items.title: What's the difference between using rclone/Zurg mounts vs. symlinks (Riven, CLI Debrid, Decypharr, etc.) in my media server?
items.text:
DUMB supports two methods of exposing content to your media server, each with its own use case:

Direct Mount (Zurg/rclone)Symlinked Mount (Riven/CLI Debrid/Decypharr)

Mounting the WebDAV or remote storage directly using rclone (which often connects to a Zurg instance) gives you full access to all files in your debrid account.

Pros:

  • Access to all debrid content, including content not added by Riven
  • Instant visibility of new files from your debrid service
  • Useful for manual browsing or catching content missed by automation
  • Allows content orchestration with Debrid Media Manager (DMM)
  • Less complexity when sharing mounts across the host or network

Cons:

  • File/folder naming is often inconsistent or messy
  • Can lead to Plex/Emby/Jellyfin misidentification
  • Media scanners may perform poorly due to large, unorganized libraries

Services like Riven, CLI Debrid, or Decypharr create cleanly named symlinks pointing to content in the underlying Zurg/rclone mount (usually in a shared directory like /mnt/debrid/riven).

These symlinks are stored in a separate directory (like /mnt/debrid/riven_symlinks) and represent only curated content that has been identified and processed.

Pros:

  • Only includes content that's been properly scraped and sorted
  • Directory structure and filenames are optimized for media servers
  • More accurate library scans and faster detection
  • Ideal for fully automated Plex/Emby/Jellyfin setups

Cons:

  • Only includes what has been processed ‚Äî not your full debrid library
  • Requires the service to stay running and correctly configured
  • If settings are misconfigured, some content may not appear
  • If the database is lost or reset, all content must be scraped and added again
  • Symlinks add complexity by requiring your media server to share the same exact container paths as defined in DUMB's dumb_config.json ‚Äî e.g., /mnt/debrid must exist exactly the same inside your media server container or on the host when the media server is not containerized

items.title: Host-Based Media Server: Mount Path Consistency
items.text:
If your media server (such as Plex) runs directly on the host (not in Docker), it will access media files using the host's file system. In this setup, any symlinks created inside the DUMB container must resolve correctly on the host. This means the media paths inside the container must exactly match the paths used by the host.

Symlink resolution is based on absolute paths. If those paths don't exist or don't match outside the container, the symlinks will be broken or unusable by the media server.

items.title: Example: Using Riven's Symlink Media Directory
items.text:
Suppose your media is mounted on the host at:

/docker/DUMB/mnt/debrid

Since Plex (or another media server) and the DUMB container need to both access this path and resolve symlinks, your Docker bind mount must look like:

/docker/DUMB/mnt/debrid:/docker/DUMB/mnt/debrid

This differs from the the default /docker/DUMB/mnt/debrid:/mnt/debrid internal path for the container by prepending /docker/DUMB or whatever the host side absolute path is for the /mnt/debrid directory

Then, inside the dumb_config.json, you would also need to make sure you define the updated internal path for symlinks:

"riven_backend": {
  "symlink_library_path": "/docker/DUMB/mnt/debrid/riven_symlinks",
}

This ensures that any symlinks Riven creates will remain valid on the host.

items.title: Simplified Approach Using Standard Paths
items.text:
To simplify configuration and reduce the need to hardcode deep paths, you can instead use standard directory mounts like /mnt.

Docker Compose example:

/mnt/debrid:/mnt/debrid

And then update the configuration:

The below is the default path used in the container when configured through the onboarding process

"riven_backend": {
  "symlink_library_path": "/mnt/debrid/riven_symlinks",
}

Using standardized top-level paths makes your setup more portable and ensures symlinks will resolve correctly regardless of the underlying directory structure.

also review the Default Mount Structure and Mount Propagation sections for additional details!

items.title: Huntarr FAQ
items.text: Common questions and fixes for Huntarr in DUMB.

items.title: Why is the Huntarr UI not loading?
items.text:
Check the following:

  • Confirm the service is enabled in dumb_config.json.
  • Verify the port in the service configuration (default 9705).
  • Review the Huntarr logs for startup errors.

Traefik access

If Traefik is enabled, you can access Huntarr at http://<host>/huntarr/.

items.title: Why doesn't Huntarr see my Arr instances?
items.text:
Huntarr relies on Arr API access.

  • Ensure Sonarr/Radarr/Lidarr are running and reachable.
  • Verify API keys are set in the Arr configs.
  • Check that core_service is set appropriately in your Arr instance configs.

items.title: Which Huntarr instance should I use?
items.text:
DUMB supports multiple Huntarr instances for different workflows.

Instance ports

  • Default instance: 9705
  • Additional instances: choose unique ports

items.title: pgAdmin FAQ
items.text: Below are common questions and helpful usage tips for working with pgAdmin in DUMB.

items.title: What is pgAdmin used for in DUMB?
items.text:
pgAdmin is a web-based GUI for managing PostgreSQL. In the context of DUMB, it connects to the PostgreSQL instance used by services like Riven and Zilean.

You can use it to:

  • Explore and modify database tables and data
  • Run SQL queries manually using the Query Tool
  • Schedule tasks using pgAgent (optional tool inside pgAdmin)
  • View the System Stats inside PostgreSQL

items.title: Using pgAdmin‚Äôs Query Tool
items.text:
To run manual queries (e.g., inspecting or modifying blacklist entries):

  1. Navigate to the "Databases" list in the left sidebar.
  2. Right-click the riven or zilean database.
  3. Select Query Tool.
  4. Paste your SQL query in the top panel and run it.

items.title: Example: View & Clear Riven's Stream Blacklist
items.text:
SELECT id, media_item_id, stream_id FROM "StreamBlacklistRelation";
DELETE FROM "StreamBlacklistRelation";

To just view the count:

SELECT COUNT(*) FROM "StreamBlacklistRelation";

items.title: Save Queries for Later
items.text: Click Save As in the Query Tool to store frequently used queries as .sql files.

items.title: Drop a Database or Create a Manual Backup in pgAdmin
Drop a Database
items.text:
You can delete a database from within pgAdmin if you no longer need it (e.g., to reset Riven or Zilean).

  1. In the Object Browser, expand the Databases section.
  2. Right-click the target database (e.g., riven or zilean).
  3. Select Delete/Drop.
  4. Confirm when prompted.

Warning

This will permanently remove the database and all its data. Ensure you‚Äôve backed up anything you want to keep before proceeding.

items.title: Manually Create a Database Backup
items.text:
To create a backup of any database using the pgAdmin interface:

  1. In the Object Browser, right-click the desired database.
  2. Choose Backup.

  3. In the dialog:

    • Format: Select Custom to enable full database restore capability.
    • Filename: Save to /pgadmin/data/your_backup_name.backup or .sql.

  4. Ensure Dump Options #1 is configured with:

    • Include CREATE DATABASE statement enabled (for standalone restoration)
    • Only data and Only schema unchecked (you want both schema and data)

  5. Under Dump Options #2, verify or set advanced filters if needed.

  6. Click Backup to start the process.

items.title: .backup vs .sql
items.text:
• .backup (Custom Format)

    • Recommended for complete backups
    • Supports compression, selective restore, and full restore via pgAdmin or pg_restore
    • Not human-readable but ideal for production-grade backups

  • .sql (Plain Format)

    • Outputs all SQL commands as text
    • Human-readable and easy to inspect or modify manually
    • Can be restored via psql, but lacks compression and selective restoration features

For a reliable, restorable snapshot of your database, always choose .backup with Custom format.

For more advanced backup configuration and explanation of options, see the pgAdmin Backup Dialog Documentation.

items.title: ‚è± Optional: Use pgAgent to Schedule Tasks
items.text:
pgAdmin comes with pgAgent, which lets you create recurring jobs.

This is entirely optional and not required to use DUMB.

items.title: Example: Scheduled Backups with pgAgent
items.text:
1. Navigate to pgAgent Jobs under your connected DUMB server.

  2. Right-click ‚Üí Create ‚Üí pgAgent Job

  3. Enter the job name and any comments.

  4. Go to the Steps tab and click the + button to Add row.

  5. Edit the new row to configure a backup step.

  6. Enter a step name, set Kind = Batch, and paste your backup command in the Code tab:

    pg_dump --username=DUMB --dbname=riven --clean --file=/pgadmin/data/riven_backup-`date +%Y-%m-%d-%H-%M-%S`.sql
pg_dump --username=DUMB --dbname=zilean --clean --file=/pgadmin/data/zilean_backup-`date +%Y-%m-%d-%H-%M-%S`.sql

  7. Go to the Schedules tab to define when the backup should run.

  8. On the Repeat tab, set a repeat interval like daily at midnight.

  9. Save your pgAgent job.

Backups are saved in /pgadmin/data by default.

items.text:

items.title: Plex FAQ
items.text: Below are some common questions and solutions related to when using Plex alongside DUMB with services like Zurg and Rclone.

items.title: Recommended Library Settings
items.text: To reduce the risk of excessive API calls to Real-Debrid (which can result in 423 Locked errors or rate limits), the following Plex library settings should be disabled for each media library:

items.title: Library Settings (Per Library):
items.text:
• Video Preview Thumbnails
  • Credits Detection
  • Voice Detection
  • Empty trash automatically after every scan (this can trigger deletions unnecessarily when using symlinked content)

items.title: Global Settings (Settings > Library):
items.text:
• Scan my library automatically
  • Run a partial scan when changes are detected

These settings reduce the number of filesystem scans Plex performs, which can otherwise generate a high number of requests to mounted Real-Debrid content.

items.title: Plex buffers a lot when playing content mounted via rclone
items.text: This is often caused by the lack of caching when streaming large files from cloud-mounted storage.

items.title: Recommended Solution
items.text:
Enable VFS (Virtual File System) cache in your rclone configuration.

When using DUMB, set the following environment variables: 

RCLONE_VFS_CACHE_MODE=full
RCLONE_VFS_CACHE_MAX_SIZE=100G
RCLONE_VFS_CACHE_MAX_AGE=6h

These flags ensure that: - The full file is cached locally before playback. - Plex can smoothly read data without constant remote fetches.

See rclone docs or refer to rclone Flags via Environment Variables for examples and formatting guidance.

items.title: Related Pages
items.text:
• Zurg FAQ
  • Rclone Configuration

items.title: PostgreSQL FAQ
items.text: Below are common questions and explanations related to PostgreSQL, which is the primary database engine used by DUMB.

items.title: How PostgreSQL is used in DUMB
items.text:
PostgreSQL is used to store persistent data for the following services:

  • Riven Backend ‚Äì stores indexed content, metadata, scraped results, job states, and user settings.
  • Zilean ‚Äì stores hash lookups, metadata cache, and processing history.

Each service has its own database, created automatically when DUMB starts:

Service Database Name Riven riven Zilean zilean pgAdmin (optional) pgadmin

The database storage path is configured using the postgres_data path in dumb_config.json, defaulting to /postgres_data.

items.title: What happens if I delete the database?
items.text:
If the PostgreSQL volume or /postgres_data directory is deleted, all data for Riven and Zilean will be lost.

This includes:

  • Indexed or scraped content in Riven
  • Cached metadata and hashes in Zilean
  • Any custom settings stored in the database

Both services will start fresh and reinitialize their databases upon next launch.

Accidental deletion of postgres_data is not recoverable

Make sure to regularly back up your postgres_data directory if long-term retention is important.

See the pgAdmin service for details on scheduling backups of the PostgreSQL databases.

items.title: Can I reset the database intentionally?
items.text:
Yes ‚Äî stopping the stack, deleting the postgres_data directory, and starting again will reset everything.

Alternatively, use pgAdmin 4 (if enabled) to drop individual databases manually.

See the PostgreSQL Useful Commands section.

Alternatively, See the pgAdmin FAQ section.

items.title: What are the default credentials?
items.text:
• Username: DUMB
  • Password: postgres
  • Port: 5432
  • These values can be customized in the postgres section of dumb_config.json.

items.title: Can I connect to PostgreSQL externally?
items.text:
Yes ‚Äî by default, PostgreSQL binds to 127.0.0.1. If you want to connect from an external app (like DBeaver or pgAdmin on your host machine), you'll need to:

  1. Change host in the postgres section of dumb_config.json to 0.0.0.0
  2. Add a port binding (e.g., 5432:5432) to your container
  3. Optionally secure with a firewall or password change

items.title: Is it safe to run queries against the databases?
items.text:
Yes ‚Äî but with caution. Direct queries using tools like pgAdmin or psql can be useful for debugging or data inspection, but changes may break app logic unless you know what you're doing.

When in doubt, make a backup first!

items.title: rclone FAQ
items.text: Below are some common questions and solutions related to using rclone with DUMB.

items.title: I think I might be rate limited by the debrid service - seeing 423 errors.
items.text: Add - RCLONE_TSP_LIMIT=10 to the environment variable section of the compose.

items.title: How do I enable rclone filtering to include only specific resolutions?
Example docker-compose to include only 4k|2160|UHD content.
items.text: Add - RCLONE_EXCLUDE=**/**{{(?i)(1080|720|480)}}** to the environment variable section of the compose.

items.title: Example docker-compose to exclude only 4k|2160|UHD content.
items.text: Add - RCLONE_EXCLUDE=**/**{{(?i)(4k|uhd|2160)}}** to the environment variable section of the compose.

items.title: Example docker-compose to include only 4k|2160|UHD content.
items.text: Add - RCLONE_FILTER_FROM=/config/filter_include_2160.txt to the environment variable section of the compose and add the below content to a filter_include_2160.txt file in the config directory for the container.

items.title: Example docker-compose to exclude only 4k|2160|UHD content.
items.text: Add - RCLONE_FILTER_FROM=/config/filter_exclude_2160.txt to the environment variable section of the compose and the below content to a filter_exclude_2160.txt file in the config directory for the container.

items.title: Error response from daemon: path /your/host/path/mnt is mounted on / but it is not a shared mount.
items.text:
From the host OS, enter sudo mount --make-rshared /

Or if using a NAS device sudo mount --make-rshared /volume1/

If neither of the above resolves the error, ensure that docker is not installed via snap. Install docker via apt.

Note

sudo mount --make-rshared does not persist reboots, so it will need to be run each time WSL2 or Windows is restarted. Alternatively, see the below guide for automatically executing the command on startup for Ubuntu.

items.title: Ubuntu systemd service:
items.text:
To make Ubuntu run a command like sudo mount --make-rshared / on startup, you can use a systemd service unit that executes this command at boot.

Systemd is a system and service manager for Linux operating systems, which allows you to specify custom startup tasks through service units.

Here's how you can do it:

items.title: Create a systemd service file:
items.text:
First, you need to create a new systemd service file. You can do this by creating a file in the /etc/systemd/system directory. Let's call this file make-rshared.service.

Open a terminal and use your favorite text editor to create this file. You'll need sudo privileges to create a file in this directory. For example, using nano:

sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/make-rshared.service

Add the following contents to the service file:

[Unit]
Description=Make root filesystem rshared
After=local-fs.target

[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/bin/mount --make-rshared /
RemainAfterExit=yes

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

items.title: Enable and start the service:
items.text:
After saving the file, you need to reload the systemd daemon to recognize your new service and then enable the service to start on boot:

sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable make-rshared.service
To start the service immediately without rebooting, you can use:

sudo systemctl start make-rshared.service

items.title: Verify the service is active:
items.text:
After rebooting or starting the service, you can check its status to ensure it's active and has run successfully:

sudo systemctl status make-rshared.service

items.title: Seerr FAQ
items.text: Common questions and fixes for Seerr in DUMB.

items.title: Why is the Seerr UI not loading?
items.text:
• Confirm the service is enabled in dumb_config.json.
  • Ensure port 5055 is available and not blocked.
  • Check logs at the configured log path for startup errors.

Traefik access

If Traefik is enabled, you can access Seerr at http://<host>/seerr/.

items.title: Seerr cannot connect to my media server
items.text:
Seerr needs API access to Plex/Jellyfin/Emby.

  • Verify the media server is running and reachable.
  • Confirm the API key/token is correct in Seerr settings.
  • If using Traefik, make sure the base URL matches the proxy path.

items.title: Why are requests failing to import into Arr?
items.text:
• Ensure Sonarr/Radarr are enabled and accessible.
  • Verify API keys in Seerr match the Arr instances.
  • Confirm the Arr instances are on the correct ports.

items.title: Tautulli FAQ
items.text: Common questions and fixes for Tautulli in DUMB.

items.title: Why is the Tautulli UI not loading?
items.text:
• Confirm Tautulli is enabled in dumb_config.json.
  • Ensure port 8181 is available.
  • Review the Tautulli log for startup errors.

Traefik access

If Traefik is enabled, you can access Tautulli at http://<host>/tautulli/.

items.title: Tautulli cannot connect to Plex
items.text:
• Confirm Plex Media Server is running.
  • Check the Plex URL and token in Tautulli settings.
  • Verify that the Plex port (32400) is reachable from the container.

items.title: Tautulli data is missing or incomplete
items.text:
• Make sure your Plex libraries have been scanned recently.
  • Check that Tautulli has permission to access Plex history and metadata.

items.title: Zilean FAQ
items.text: Below are some common questions and solutions related to Zilean when used with DUMB.

items.title: Why is Zilean spamming my logs!?!
items.text:
This is normal for a first-time run of Zilean.

Zilean parses all the Debrid Media Manager (DMM) hash lists and saves them into the PostgreSQL database.

Then, it will run a scheduled update to add/remove any new hash content.

Depending on the system, the first-time run can take hours to days.

items.title: Zurg FAQ
items.text: Below are some common questions and solutions related to Zurg when used with DUMB.

items.title: ERROR - rclone w/ RealDebrid subprocess: : IO error: File is temporarily unavailable: 423 Locked
items.text:
This error generally indicates that a rate limit is being enforced by Real-Debrid. It often occurs during media server scans that hit the API too frequently.

To mitigate this: - If you're using Plex, this is commonly caused by automatic scans that trigger repeatedly. - Alternatively, you may also need to impose a transactions (requests) per second limit with rclone.

See the Plex FAQ for more Plex-specific recommendations and details. See the rclone FAQ for more rclone-specific recommendations and details.

items.title: Related Pages
items.text: • Zurg Configuration

items.title: What is DUMB?
items.text: DUMB (Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge) is an all-in-one media management solution designed to streamline the process of finding, downloading, organizing, and streaming media content. It integrates multiple services into a single Docker image, providing automation and efficiency for managing media libraries.

items.title: Key Features
items.text:
• Unified Deployment ‚Äì Combines multiple tools into a single, easy-to-deploy system with onboarding-driven setup.
  • Built-In Media Server Integration ‚Äì Includes Plex Media Server, Jellyfin, and Emby, fully embedded in the container to eliminate mount propagation issues.
  • Automated Content Management ‚Äì Uses Debrid and Usenet services alongside Plex Discover Watchlists, Trakt lists, and Seerr to automate media retrieval.
  • Arr + WebDAV Workflows ‚Äì Supports Sonarr, Radarr, Lidarr, Whisparr, plus WebDAV-driven clients like Decypharr (Debrid) and NzbDAV (Usenet).
  • Huntarr automation ‚Äì Optional continuous searches to fill missing content and upgrade quality.
  • Seerr Sync ‚Äì One-way request replication from a primary Seerr to subordinate instances for multi-household or multi-stack setups.
  • Integrated Web UI ‚Äì Control and manage services through a simple web-based interface.
  • Authentication ‚Äì Optional JWT-based security with user management and session handling.
  • Auto-update ‚Äì Keep services current with automatic updates from GitHub releases, nightly builds, or specific branches.
  • Symlink Operations ‚Äì End-to-end guide for repair, migration, backup/restore, scheduled snapshots, and path-transition playbooks.
  • Modular Design ‚Äì Each service (Riven, Zurg, Zilean, etc.) is independently configurable and upgradable.
  • Advanced Logging & Monitoring ‚Äì View and filter service logs directly from the DUMB Frontend.
  • FFprobe monitor ‚Äì Background worker that detects and unsticks ffprobe scans in Sonarr/Radarr.
  • Real-Time Metrics ‚Äì Monitor CPU, memory, disk, and network usage with WebSocket-powered live updates.

items.title: Core Components
items.text: DUMB integrates the following projects to create a seamless media experience:

items.title: Riven
items.text: Riven is one of multiple options responsible for content management, handling search queries, downloading, and organizing media for streaming.

items.title: CLI Debrid
items.text: CLI Debrid is one of multiple options responsible for content management, handling search queries, downloading, and organizing media for streaming.

items.title: Decypharr
items.text: Decypharr is a Debrid-focused option responsible for content management, handling search queries, downloading, and organizing media for streaming.

items.title: NzbDAV
items.text: NzbDAV provides an NZB WebDAV gateway and Arr download-client integration for Usenet workflows.

items.title: Prowlarr
items.text: Prowlarr centralizes indexer management and syncs indexers across the Arr stack.

items.title: Arrs (Sonarr/Radarr/Lidarr/Whisparr)
items.text: The Arrs handle TV, movies, music, and adult content automation and organization. During onboarding, selecting Decypharr or NzbDAV can wire Arr instances automatically.

items.title: Huntarr
items.text: Huntarr automates missing-content and quality-upgrade searches across the Arr stack. DUMB can filter Huntarr instances by core_service to keep Debrid and Usenet workflows separate.

items.title: Zurg
items.text: Zurg acts as the automation engine that interacts with Real-Debrid to fetch media files.

items.title: Zilean
items.text: Zilean enhances content discovery and caching, optimizing the efficiency of media lookups.

items.title: rclone
items.text: rclone manages cloud storage connections and allows mounting remote debrid storage as if it were a local drive.

items.title: Plex Media Server
items.text: Plex is bundled directly inside DUMB, providing internal access to rclone-mounted content without needing to expose paths via external bind mounts.

items.title: Jellyfin & Emby
items.text: Jellyfin and Emby are alternative media servers supported inside the same container.

items.title: PostgreSQL & pgAdmin 4
items.text:
• PostgreSQL serves as the primary database for storing metadata, configurations, and user preferences.
  • pgAdmin 4 provides a web-based database management interface, making it easy to manage PostgreSQL.

items.title: How Does It Work?
items.text:
DUMB simplifies the media management workflow by:

  1. Run Onboarding to select core services and auto-enable required dependencies.
  2. Scan Lists & Requests from Plex, Trakt, and Seerr.
  3. Fetch From Debrid or Usenet providers (Real-Debrid, AllDebrid, etc.).
  4. Route Through Orchestrators (Riven/CLI Debrid) or Arr clients (Decypharr/NzbDAV).
  5. Mount & Organize Content via Zurg + rclone and Arr-managed libraries.
  6. Stream via Plex/Jellyfin/Emby using internal paths and embedded media servers.

items.title: Next Steps
items.text: Explore the Configuration section to understand how to set up and customize DUMB according to your needs.

items.title: Authentication
items.text: DUMB includes an optional JWT-based authentication system to secure access to the API and web interface. Authentication can be enabled during initial setup or at any time through the settings page.

items.title: Overview
items.text:
The authentication system provides:

  • JWT token-based security with access and refresh tokens
  • User management with create, update, and delete capabilities
  • First-time setup wizard for creating the initial admin user
  • Optional authentication - can be skipped for local/trusted environments
  • Session persistence with "Remember Me" functionality

items.title: Authentication flow
items.text:
flowchart TD
    A[App Start] --> B{Auth Status Check}
    B -->|No Users Exist| C[Setup Page]
    B -->|Auth Disabled| D[Dashboard]
    B -->|Auth Enabled| E{Token Valid?}
    E -->|Yes| D
    E -->|No| F[Login Page]
    C -->|Create User| G[Auth Enabled]
    C -->|Skip Setup| H[Auth Disabled]
    G --> D
    H --> D
    F -->|Login Success| D

items.title: First-time setup
items.text: When DUMB starts for the first time, the frontend detects that no users exist and redirects to the setup page.

items.title: Setup options
items.text:
Create admin accountSkip authentication
  1. Navigate to the DUMB frontend (default: http://localhost:3005)
  2. You will be redirected to /setup
  3. Enter a username and password
  4. Click Create Account
  5. Authentication is automatically enabled
  6. You are logged in and redirected to the dashboard
  1. Navigate to the DUMB frontend
  2. On the setup page, click Skip Setup
  3. Authentication remains disabled
  4. All API endpoints are accessible without tokens
  5. You can enable authentication later in Settings

Security consideration

Skipping authentication is only recommended for local development or fully isolated environments. If your DUMB instance is accessible from the network, enable authentication to protect your services.

items.title: Login process
items.text: When authentication is enabled, users must log in to access the dashboard and API.

items.title: Login steps
items.text:
1. Navigate to the DUMB frontend
  2. Enter your username and password
  3. Optionally check Remember Me for persistent sessions
  4. Click Login

items.title: Token management
items.text:
Token Type Lifetime Storage Purpose Access Token 60 minutes Session/Local Storage API requests Refresh Token 30 days Session/Local Storage Obtain new access tokens
  • Remember Me checked: Tokens stored in localStorage (persist across browser sessions)
  • Remember Me unchecked: Tokens stored in sessionStorage (cleared when browser closes)

items.title: User management
items.text: Administrators can manage users through the Settings page or API.

items.title: Available operations
items.text:
Operation Description Create User Add a new user with username and password Disable User Temporarily disable a user account Enable User Re-enable a disabled user account Delete User Permanently remove a user account

Last active user protection

The last active (non-disabled) user cannot be disabled or deleted. This prevents accidentally locking yourself out of the system.

items.title: Managing users via settings
items.text:
1. Navigate to Settings in the sidebar
  2. Scroll to the User Management section
  3. Use the interface to add, disable, or delete users

items.title: Enabling or disabling authentication
items.text: Authentication can be toggled at any time through the Settings page.

items.title: Enable authentication
items.text:
1. Go to Settings
  2. Find the Authentication section
  3. Click Enable Authentication
  4. If no users exist, you will be prompted to create one

items.title: Disable authentication
items.text:
1. Go to Settings
  2. Find the Authentication section
  3. Click Disable Authentication
  4. All API endpoints become accessible without tokens

Security warning

Disabling authentication exposes all DUMB functionality to anyone who can reach the API. Only disable authentication in trusted, isolated environments.

items.title: API authentication
items.text: When authentication is enabled, all API requests require a valid JWT token in the Authorization header.

items.title: Request format
items.text:
curl -X GET http://localhost:8000/api/process/processes \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer <access_token>"

items.title: WebSocket authentication
items.text:
WebSocket connections pass the token as a query parameter:

const ws = new WebSocket('ws://localhost:8000/ws/status?token=<access_token>');

items.title: Handling token expiration
items.text:
When an access token expires, the API returns a 401 Unauthorized response. The frontend automatically:

  1. Catches the 401 response
  2. Sends the refresh token to /api/auth/refresh
  3. Receives new access and refresh tokens
  4. Retries the original request

If the refresh token is also expired, the user is redirected to the login page.

items.title: Configuration
items.text:
Authentication state is stored in /config/users.json:

{
  "version": 2,
  "jwt_secret": "auto-generated-secret-key",
  "auth_enabled": true,
  "setup_skipped": false,
  "users": [
    {
      "username": "admin",
      "hashed_password": "$2b$12$...",
      "disabled": false
    }
  ]
}
Field Description version Schema version for migrations jwt_secret Auto-generated secret for signing tokens auth_enabled Whether authentication is required setup_skipped Whether initial setup was skipped users Array of user accounts

Password security

Passwords are hashed using bcrypt with automatic salt generation. The original password is never stored.

items.title: "Invalid credentials" error
items.text:
• Verify the username is spelled correctly (case-sensitive)
  • Ensure the password is correct
  • Check if the user account is disabled

items.title: "Token expired" errors
items.text:
• The frontend should automatically refresh tokens
  • If issues persist, try logging out and back in
  • Clear browser storage and re-authenticate

items.title: Locked out of the system
items.text:
If you cannot access your account:

  1. Stop the DUMB container
  2. Edit /config/users.json
  3. Set "auth_enabled": false
  4. Restart the container
  5. Access the dashboard and create a new user or reset your password

items.title: Related pages
items.text:
• Authentication API
  • WebSocket API
  • DUMB Frontend

items.title: Auto-restart
items.text: DUMB includes an automatic restart system that monitors service health and restarts failed services to maintain system stability without manual intervention.

items.title: Overview
items.text:
The auto-restart system provides:

  • Health monitoring - Periodic health checks for each service
  • Automatic recovery - Restart services that become unhealthy
  • Exponential backoff - Increasing delays between restart attempts
  • Restart limits - Prevent infinite restart loops
  • Grace periods - Allow services time to initialize

items.title: How it works
items.text:
%%{ init: { "flowchart": { "curve": "basis" } } }%%
flowchart TD
    A([Service running])
    B{Health check}
    C{Threshold exceeded?}
    D{Restart limit reached?}
    E[Restart service]
    F([Stop retrying])
    G[Wait grace period]

    A ==> B
    B -- Healthy --> A
    B -- Unhealthy --> C
    C -- No --> B
    C -- Yes --> D
    D -- Not reached --> E
    D -- Reached --> F
    E ==> G
    G ==> B
  1. Health check - Service is periodically checked for responsiveness
  2. Unhealthy detection - Multiple consecutive failures trigger action
  3. Restart attempt - Service is stopped and restarted
  4. Grace period - Wait for service to initialize
  5. Repeat - Continue monitoring after restart

items.title: Configuration
items.text:
Auto-restart is configured globally in dumb.auto_restart:

"dumb": {
  "auto_restart": {
    "enabled": false,
    "restart_on_unhealthy": true,
    "healthcheck_interval": 30,
    "unhealthy_threshold": 3,
    "max_restarts": 3,
    "window_seconds": 300,
    "backoff_seconds": [5, 15, 45, 120],
    "grace_period_seconds": 30,
    "services": []
  }
}

items.title: Configuration options
items.text: Option Default Description enabled false Enable auto-restart globally restart_on_unhealthy true Restart when health checks fail healthcheck_interval 30 Seconds between health checks unhealthy_threshold 3 Consecutive failures before restart max_restarts 3 Maximum restarts within the window window_seconds 300 Time window in seconds backoff_seconds [5, 15, 45, 120] Backoff delays between restarts grace_period_seconds 30 Seconds to wait after restart before health checks services [] Limit auto-restart to these process names

items.title: Exponential backoff
items.text:
To prevent rapid restart loops, delays between restarts increase exponentially:

Attempt Delay 1 5 seconds 2 10 seconds 3 20 seconds 4 40 seconds 5 80 seconds 6+ 120 seconds (max)

The formula: delay = min(initial_delay * (backoff_multiplier ^ attempt), max_delay)

items.title: Restart limits
items.text:
Services have a maximum number of restart attempts within a time window:

  • Default: 5 restarts per hour
  • After reaching the limit, auto-restart pauses for that service
  • The counter resets after the window expires
  • Manual restart resets the counter

Restart limit reached

If a service keeps failing, investigate the root cause rather than increasing limits. Check logs for error messages.

items.title: Health checks
items.text: Services are monitored using health check endpoints or process status:

items.title: HTTP health checks
items.text:
For services with web interfaces:

"health_check": {
  "type": "http",
  "url": "http://127.0.0.1:8080/health",
  "timeout": 10,
  "interval": 30
}

items.title: Process health checks
items.text:
For services without HTTP endpoints:

"health_check": {
  "type": "process",
  "interval": 30
}

items.title: Dashboard indicators
items.text:
The dashboard shows auto-restart status for each service:

  • Restart count - Number of restarts in current window
  • Last restart - Timestamp of most recent restart
  • Health status - Current healthy/unhealthy state

items.title: API endpoints
items.text:
Query restart status via the API:

# Get service status including restart info
curl http://localhost:8000/api/process/service-status?process_name=Riven%20Backend

Response includes:

{
  "process_name": "Riven Backend",
  "status": "running",
  "healthy": true,
  "restart": {
    "count": 2,
    "last_restart": "2025-01-15T10:30:00Z",
    "enabled": true
  }
}

items.title: WebSocket updates
items.text:
Real-time restart events via /ws/status:

{
  "type": "status",
  "processes": [
    {
      "process_name": "Riven Backend",
      "status": "running",
      "healthy": true,
      "restart": {
        "count": 2,
        "last_restart": "2025-01-15T10:30:00Z",
        "enabled": true
      }
    }
  ]
}

items.title: Per-service
items.text:
Disable for a specific service:

"riven_backend": {
  "auto_restart": {
    "enabled": false
  }
}

items.title: Globally
items.text: To disable auto-restart for all services, set enabled: false in each service's auto_restart configuration, or use the Settings page in the frontend.

items.title: Appropriate thresholds
items.text:
• Critical services (Plex, rclone): Lower threshold (2-3)
  • Background services (Zilean, Huntarr): Higher threshold (3-5)

items.title: Grace periods
items.text:
• Fast-starting services: 10-15 seconds
  • Database-dependent services: 30-60 seconds
  • Services with startup tasks: 60-120 seconds

items.title: Monitoring
items.text:
• Review restart counts regularly
  • Investigate services with frequent restarts
  • Check logs after restart events

items.title: Service keeps restarting
items.text:
1. Check service logs for errors
  2. Verify configuration is valid
  3. Ensure dependencies are running
  4. Check for port conflicts

items.title: Auto-restart not working
items.text:
1. Verify auto_restart.enabled is true
  2. Check if restart limit was reached
  3. Ensure health check is configured correctly

items.title: Restart delay too long
items.text:
• Reduce backoff_multiplier
  • Lower max_delay
  • Reset counter with manual restart

items.title: Related pages
items.text:
• Dashboard - View restart status
  • Process Management API - API controls
  • WebSocket API - Real-time updates

items.title: Auto-update
items.text: DUMB includes a comprehensive auto-update system that keeps your services current with the latest releases. Each service can be configured independently with different update strategies, from fully automatic updates to version pinning.

items.title: Overview
items.text:
The auto-update system supports multiple update strategies:

Strategy Description Use Case Latest Release Tracks the latest stable GitHub release with scheduled checks Production environments Nightly Builds Tracks nightly GitHub releases with scheduled checks Testing new features Prerelease Tracks prerelease GitHub builds with scheduled checks Beta testing Branch-based Downloads directly from a Git branch on setup/startup Development Version Pinning Locks to a specific version without scheduled updates Stability critical

items.title: How it works
items.text:
%%{ init: { "flowchart": { "curve": "basis" } } }%%
flowchart TD
    A([Service startup])
    B{Auto-update enabled?}
    C[Check for updates]
    D([Start service])
    E{Update available?}
    F[Download update]
    G[Stop service]
    H[Apply update]
    I([Start service])
    J[Schedule next check]
    K[Wait for interval]

    A ==> B
    B -- No --> D
    B -- Yes --> C
    C ==> E
    E -- No --> D
    E -- Yes --> F
    F ==> G
    G ==> H
    H ==> I
    I ==> J
    J ==> K
    K ==> C

items.title: Update lifecycle
items.text:
1. Initial check - When a service starts, DUMB checks for available updates
  2. Version comparison - Current version is compared with the latest available
  3. Download - If an update is available, the new version is downloaded
  4. Apply - The service is stopped, updated, and restarted
  5. Schedule - Future update checks are scheduled based on the configured interval

items.title: Configuration
items.text:
Auto-update settings are configured per-service in dumb_config.json:

{
  "service_name": {
    "enabled": true,
    "auto_update": true,
    "auto_update_start_time": "04:00",
    "auto_update_interval": 24,
    "release_version_enabled": false,
    "release_version": "latest",
    "branch_enabled": false,
    "branch": "main",
    "pinned_version": "",
    "clear_on_update": true,
    "exclude_dirs": []
  }
}

items.title: Configuration options
items.text:
Option Type Default Description auto_update boolean false Enable automatic updates for this service auto_update_start_time string "04:00" 24-hour schedule anchor time (HH:MM) auto_update_interval number 24 Hours between update checks release_version_enabled boolean false Use release version strategy release_version string "latest" Target version: latest, nightly, prerelease, or specific version branch_enabled boolean false Use branch-based deployment branch string "main" Git branch to track pinned_version string "" Pin to specific version (disables auto-update) clear_on_update boolean true Clear working directory before update exclude_dirs array [] Directories to preserve during updates

Auto-update and strategy interaction

Automatic scheduling is disabled when pinned_version, release_version_enabled, or branch_enabled are set. The only exception is when release_version is nightly or prerelease, which keeps scheduled checks enabled.

items.title: Latest release (default)
items.text:
The default strategy fetches the latest stable release from GitHub:

{
  "frontend": {
    "auto_update": true,
    "auto_update_start_time": "04:00",
    "auto_update_interval": 24
  }
}

This checks GitHub's /releases/latest endpoint and downloads the newest stable version.

items.title: Nightly builds
items.text:
For testing cutting-edge features, enable nightly builds:

{
  "service_name": {
    "release_version_enabled": true,
    "release_version": "nightly"
  }
}

Nightly version format

Nightly builds use date-based versioning like v2025.01.22.nightly. Version comparison checks the first three parts (year, month, day).

items.title: Prerelease versions
items.text:
To receive beta or release candidate versions:

{
  "service_name": {
    "release_version_enabled": true,
    "release_version": "prerelease"
  }
}

Prerelease scheduling

When release_version is prerelease, scheduled auto-update checks continue to run at your configured interval.

items.title: Branch-based deployment
items.text:
Track a specific Git branch for development or testing:

{
  "service_name": {
    "branch_enabled": true,
    "branch": "dev"
  }
}

Branch-based updates

Branch-based deployment downloads the latest commit from the specified branch during setup/startup. Scheduled auto-update checks are disabled when branch_enabled is true.

items.title: Version pinning
items.text:
Lock a service to a specific version:

{
  "service_name": {
    "pinned_version": "v1.30.0"
  }
}

When to pin versions

Pin versions when:

  • A specific version is required for compatibility
  • You need to prevent unexpected changes
  • Testing a specific release
  • Production stability is critical

Pinned versions and auto-update

Setting pinned_version disables scheduled updates for that service.

items.title: Update intervals
items.text:
The auto_update_start_time and auto_update_interval settings control update cadence:

Interval Check Frequency Recommended For 6 Every 6 hours Nightly/prerelease testing 24 Daily (default) Most services 168 Weekly Stable, critical services 
{
  "frontend": {
    "auto_update": true,
    "auto_update_start_time": "04:00",
    "auto_update_interval": 24
  }
}

With this example, checks run once per day at 04:00. If you set auto_update_interval to another value (for example 12), checks run every 12 hours anchored from the configured start time.

items.title: Clear on update
items.text:
By default, DUMB clears the service directory before applying updates. This ensures a clean installation:

{
  "service_name": {
    "clear_on_update": true
  }
}

items.title: Excluding directories
items.text:
To preserve specific directories during updates (like configuration or data):

{
  "service_name": {
    "clear_on_update": true,
    "exclude_dirs": ["config", "data", "logs"]
  }
}

items.title: Rate limiting
items.text:
GitHub's API has rate limits:

Authentication Requests per Hour Unauthenticated 60 With token 5,000

items.title: Using a GitHub token
items.text:
For higher rate limits, add a GitHub token to your configuration:

{
  "dumb": {
    "github_token": "ghp_xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx"
  }
}

Token permissions

The GitHub token only needs public_repo read access for checking releases.

Protect your token

Treat GitHub tokens as secrets. Never commit them to source control or share them in logs/screenshots.

items.title: Service-specific behavior
items.text:
Different services have specialized update handling:

Service Type Update Method Arr Suite (Sonarr, Radarr, etc.) Binary installation Plex Media Server System package installer Jellyfin System package installer Emby System package installer GitHub-based (Frontend, Huntarr, etc.) Release download and extraction

Strategy support varies

Not every service supports every strategy. For example, Arr services and Plex/Jellyfin/Emby use native installers, while GitHub-based services rely on release or branch downloads.

items.title: Check current versions
items.text:
View installed versions in the frontend:

  1. Navigate to Settings
  2. Check the Version display for each service

items.title: Update logs
items.text:
Update activity is logged to the DUMB logs:

INFO - [Auto-Update] Checking for updates: frontend
INFO - [Auto-Update] Update available: v1.32.0 -> v1.33.0
INFO - [Auto-Update] Downloading update...
INFO - [Auto-Update] Update complete: frontend v1.33.0

items.title: Updates not running
items.text:
1. Verify auto_update is enabled in the service configuration
  2. Check the interval - updates may not be due yet
  3. Review logs for error messages
  4. Verify network connectivity to GitHub

items.title: Update fails repeatedly
items.text:
1. Check GitHub API rate limits - add a token if needed
  2. Verify disk space is available
  3. Check file permissions in the service directory
  4. Review logs for specific error messages

items.title: Service won't start after update
items.text:
1. Check compatibility between the new version and your configuration
  2. Review the service's changelog for breaking changes
  3. Consider pinning to the previous working version
  4. Check logs for startup errors

items.title: Best practices
items.text:
Recommendations

  • Test updates in a non-production environment first
  • Use version pinning for critical services
  • Set appropriate intervals based on service stability needs
  • Monitor logs after updates for any issues
  • Keep backups of configuration files
  • Add a GitHub token to avoid rate limiting

items.title: Related pages
items.text:
• Configuration Guide
  • Auto-restart
  • Settings Page

items.title: Overview
items.text:
DUMB relies on a centralized configuration file, dumb_config.json, to control its services, logging, API settings, and more. This file allows you to customize the behavior of DUMB without modifying the source code.

DUMB also supports environment variables, .env files, and Docker secrets. If the same setting is defined in multiple places, the precedence is as follows:

Configuration Precedence

  1. Environment Variables (highest priority)
  2. .env File
  3. Docker Secrets
  4. dumb_config.json (lowest priority)
%%{ init: { "flowchart": { "curve": "basis" } } }%%
flowchart TD
    ENV([Environment variables])
    DOT([.env file])
    SEC([Docker secrets])
    CFG[(dumb_config.json)]
    MERGE[Resolved configuration]
    API[DUMB API]
    PH[Process handler]
    SVC[Managed services]

    ENV ==> MERGE
    DOT ==> MERGE
    SEC ==> MERGE
    CFG ==> MERGE
    MERGE ==> API
    API ==> PH
    PH ==> SVC

items.title: Configuration File Structure
items.text:
Be Careful When Modifying dumb_config.json

While DUMB is highly configurable via dumb_config.json, some changes can cause failures during startup. As such, it is not recommended to make modifications unless you fully understand their impact.

Below is the general structure of dumb_config.json:

{
    "puid": 1000,
    "pgid": 1000,
    "tz": "",
    "data_root": "/data",
    "dumb": { ... },
    "traefik": { ... },
    "cli_debrid": { ... },
    "cli_battery": { ... },
    "decypharr": { ... },
    "nzbdav": { ... },
    "emby": { ... },
    "jellyfin": { ... },
    "lidarr": { ... },
    "phalanx_db": { ... },
    "plex": { ... },
    "tautulli": { ... },
    "huntarr": { ... },
    "seerr": { ... },
    "plex_debrid": { ... },
    "postgres": { ... },
    "pgadmin": { ... },
    "prowlarr": { ... },
    "rclone": { ... },
    "riven_backend": { ... },
    "riven_frontend": { ... },
    "radarr": { ... },
    "sonarr": { ... },
    "whisparr": { ... },
    "zilean": { ... },
    "zurg": { ... }
}

Each section configures a specific service.

Below is a breakdown of some of the sections:

items.title: User & Timezone
items.text:
"puid": 1000,
"pgid": 1000,
"tz": "",
"data_root": "/data"
  • puid / pgid ‚Äì Define the user and group IDs for container execution.
  • tz ‚Äì Set the timezone (e.g., America/New_York).
  • data_root ‚Äì Base path for service data directories.

Root User Not Allowed

puid/pgid cannot be set to 0 (root). DUMB requires a non-root user for security reasons.

items.title: Logging Settings
items.text:
Located in dumb: 

"log_level": "INFO",
"log_name": "DUMB",
"log_dir": "/log",
"log_count": 2,
"log_size": "10M",
"color_log": true

  • log_level ‚Äì Set the logging verbosity (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR).
  • log_dir ‚Äì Directory where logs are stored.
  • log_count ‚Äì Number of rotated logs to retain.
  • log_size ‚Äì Maximum log file size before rotation.
  • color_log ‚Äì Enables colored log output.

items.title: Integration Tokens & Credentials
items.text:
Located in the dumb section of dumb_config.json:

"plex_token": "",
"plex_address": "",
"github_token": "",
"github_username": ""

items.title: Plex Integration
items.text:
• plex_token ‚Äì This token is used by Riven backend for interacting with your Plex account. It allows features such as using watchlists and sending library scan requests to the Plex server.
  • plex_address ‚Äì The internal or external URL of your Plex server (e.g., http://127.0.0.1:32400).

These values are used automatically by Riven when setting up the Riven Backend.

items.title: GitHub Integration
items.text:
• github_token ‚Äì Used to increase GitHub API rate limits and unlock access to private/sponsored repositories such as zurg when associated with your GitHub account.
  • github_username ‚Äì (Reserved for future use) Will support additional GitHub-sourced services and contributor personalization.

To create a GitHub token:

  1. Go to GitHub Developer Settings ‚Üí Tokens (Classic)
  2. Click Generate new token (classic)

  3. Set an expiration and enable the following scopes:

    • repo:all
    • write:packages
    • read:packages

  4. Click Generate token and copy the token ‚Äî it will only be shown once

  5. Add the token to your .env file or docker compose with DMB_GITHUB_TOKEN=, or dumb_config.json under "github_token"

items.title: Service Configuration
items.text:
Each DUMB-integrated service is configured within its own section of dumb_config.json.

See the individual service pages for in-depth configuration details:

  • DUMB API
  • DUMB Frontend
  • Decypharr
  • CLI Debrid
  • NzbDAV
  • Plex Media Server
  • Jellyfin
  • Emby
  • Sonarr
  • Radarr
  • Lidarr
  • Prowlarr
  • Whisparr
  • pgAdmin 4
  • PostgreSQL
  • rclone
  • Riven Backend
  • Riven Frontend
  • Zilean
  • Zurg

items.title: core_service (Arr integration)
items.text:
Some services (notably the Arrs) include a core_service field to tell DUMB which core workflow(s) they should attach to. This field accepts a single value, a comma-separated string, or a list.

See the Core Service Routing reference for detailed behavior and examples.

Allowed values:

  • "" (blank): no core integration
  • decypharr: route Arr automation through Decypharr
  • nzbdav: route Arr automation through NzbDAV

To combine workflows, use a list or a comma-separated core_service.

Examples:

"sonarr": {
  "instances": {
    "Default": {
      "core_service": "decypharr"
    }
  }
}

"radarr": {
  "instances": {
    "Default": {
      "core_service": "nzbdav"
    }
  }
}

"whisparr": {
  "instances": {
    "Combined": {
      "core_service": ["decypharr", "nzbdav"]
    }
  }
}

items.title: Next Steps
items.text:
1. Review and modify dumb_config.json as needed.
  2. Review the Usage page.
  3. For a deep dive into individual services, see the Services section.

items.title: Embedded Service UIs
items.text: DUMB can proxy service web interfaces through Traefik, allowing you to access all service UIs from a single entry point without exposing individual ports.

items.title: Overview
items.text:
The embedded UI feature provides:

  • Unified access - All service UIs available through one port
  • Simplified networking - No need to expose multiple ports
  • Integrated experience - Access services without leaving DUMB
  • Traefik routing - Dynamic path-based routing to services

items.title: How it works
items.text:
%%{ init: { "flowchart": { "curve": "basis" } } }%%
flowchart TD
    A([Browser])
    B[[Traefik :18080]]
    C{Path router}
    D[Riven :3000]
    E[pgAdmin :5050]
    F[Seerr :5055]
    G[Radarr :7878]

    A ==> B
    B ==> C
    C -- /service/ui/riven --> D
    C -- /service/ui/pgadmin --> E
    C -- /service/ui/seerr --> F
    C -- /service/ui/radarr --> G
  1. Request arrives at Traefik on port 18080
  2. Path matching routes to the appropriate service
  3. Middleware strips the prefix and adjusts headers
  4. Service responds through the proxy

items.title: During onboarding
items.text: The onboarding wizard asks if you want to enable embedded service UIs. Select Yes to configure Traefik routing automatically.

items.title: Via settings
items.text:
1. Navigate to Settings
  2. Find the Embedded UIs section
  3. Toggle Enable Service UIs

items.title: Via API
items.text:
curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/api/config/service-ui \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"enabled": true}'

items.title: Accessing embedded UIs
items.text:
When enabled, service UIs are available at:

http://<host>:18080/service/ui/<service_name>

The DUMB frontend also proxies UI requests through a /ui/<service_name> path for iframes and split view. Direct browser navigation to /ui/<service_name> is blocked by the frontend proxy; use the service page or the direct-link button instead.

items.title: Available services
items.text:
Service Path Native Port Riven Frontend /service/ui/riven_frontend 3000 pgAdmin 4 /service/ui/pgadmin 5050 Seerr /service/ui/seerr 5055 Tautulli /service/ui/tautulli 8181 Radarr /service/ui/radarr 7878 Sonarr /service/ui/sonarr 8989 Lidarr /service/ui/lidarr 8686 Prowlarr /service/ui/prowlarr 9696 Whisparr /service/ui/whisparr 6969 Jellyfin /service/ui/jellyfin 8096 Emby /service/ui/emby 8096 Zilean /service/ui/zilean 8182 CLI Debrid /service/ui/cli_debrid 5000 CLI Battery /service/ui/cli_battery 5001 Huntarr (instance) /service/ui/huntarr_<instance> 9705 Traefik Dashboard /service/ui/traefik 18081

Dynamic availability

Only enabled services appear in the embedded UI list. The paths are generated based on your dumb_config.json configuration.

items.title: Traefik configuration
items.text: DUMB automatically generates Traefik routing configuration in /config/traefik/services.yaml.

items.title: Example configuration
items.text:
http:
  routers:
    riven_frontend:
      rule: "PathPrefix(`/service/ui/riven_frontend`)"
      service: riven_frontend
      middlewares:
        - riven_frontend-stripprefix
        - riven_frontend-replace
        - ui_frame_headers

  middlewares:
    riven_frontend-stripprefix:
      stripPrefix:
        prefixes:
          - "/service/ui/riven_frontend"

    riven_frontend-replace:
      replacePathRegex:
        regex: "^/$"
        replacement: "/web/index.html"

    ui_frame_headers:
      headers:
        customFrameOptionsValue: "SAMEORIGIN"
        contentSecurityPolicy: "frame-ancestors 'self'"

  services:
    riven_frontend:
      loadBalancer:
        servers:
          - url: "http://127.0.0.1:3000"

items.title: Middleware chain
items.text:
Each service uses a middleware chain:

  1. stripPrefix - Removes /service/ui/<name> from the path
  2. replacePathRegex - Rewrites root path to service entry point
  3. ui_frame_headers - Adds headers for iframe embedding

items.title: iframe embedding
items.text: The DUMB frontend can display service UIs in iframes for a seamless experience:

items.title: Embedded UI tab
items.text:
Each service page includes an embedded UI tab when the service exposes a UI. From there you can:

  • Switch between available UI base paths when the service exposes multiple entry points
  • Open the UI in a new browser tab using the proxied direct link
  • Expand the UI into a full-window view without leaving the service page

items.title: Split view mode
items.text:
1. Open a service from the dashboard
  2. Click the split view button
  3. The service UI loads in a side panel

items.title: Full iframe mode
items.text: Some pages display the service UI in a full iframe, maintaining DUMB navigation while showing the service interface.

items.title: Same-origin policy
items.text: Embedded UIs are served from the same origin (Traefik port), avoiding cross-origin restrictions.

items.title: Frame headers
items.text:
The ui_frame_headers middleware sets:

  • X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN - Only allow framing from same origin
  • Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self' - Modern browsers CSP

items.title: Authentication passthrough
items.text:
When DUMB authentication is enabled:

  • The DUMB frontend handles auth
  • Service UIs may have their own auth (e.g., Plex, pgAdmin)
  • Traefik does not add authentication to proxied services

Service-level authentication

Embedded UIs inherit their own authentication requirements. Configure service-specific credentials as needed.

items.title: Service UI not loading
items.text:
1. Verify the service is running
  2. Check the service appears in /api/config/service-ui
  3. Verify Traefik configuration in /config/traefik/services.yaml
  4. Check Traefik logs for routing errors

items.title: "Refused to display in frame" error
items.text:
• Ensure ui_frame_headers middleware is applied
  • Some services have their own frame protection - check service settings
  • Try accessing the service directly to verify it works

items.title: 404 errors on service paths
items.text:
• Verify the service name matches the configuration
  • Check if the path prefix is correct
  • Ensure Traefik has reloaded the configuration

items.title: Slow loading
items.text:
• Services load their full UI through the proxy
  • Initial load may be slower than direct access
  • Consider the service's native performance

items.title: Proxy behavior and restrictions
items.text:
